title: Enriquez v. SCDOC
description: This case involves dismissal of a suit for insufficient service of process.
text:
Charleston Bldg Owners v. Builder's FirstSource


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Anthony M. Enriquez, Respondent,
				v.
				South Carolina Department of Corrections, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Marlboro County
Alison Renee Lee, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26355
Heard May 23, 2007 - Filed July 2, 2007Â  
AFFIRMED  


	
		
			
				Andrew F. Lindemann, of Davidson, Morrison & Lindemann, P.A., of Columbia; and Andrew McLeod, of Harris, McLeod and Ruffner, of Cheraw, for appellant.
				John B. Shupper, of Columbia, for respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  This appeal is from an order sanctioning appellant South Carolina Department of Corrections (SCDOC) for a discovery violation.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Respondent Anthony Enriquez commenced this action against SCDOC for allegedly failing to prevent a beating inflicted by other prisoners while he was incarcerated.Â  On the second day of trial, during questioning by Enriquezâ€™s counsel, a corrections officer revealed that he had filed an incident report following the altercation.Â  Counsel requested a copy of the report which SCDOC then produced during a break in testimony along with other documents that had not been previously disclosed.[1]Â  After examining the documents, counsel moved for sanctions claiming that the new documents identified other witnesses and would have affected his evaluation of Enriquezâ€™s case. 
 
The trial judge found sanctions were appropriate and ordered SCDOC to pay $3,000 in attorneyâ€™s fees based on counselâ€™s representation of his hourly fee for two days of trial and long distance travel.Â 
 
ISSUE
Does Rule 37, SCRCP, authorize sanctions in this case?
DISCUSSION
SCDOC contends Rule 37, SCRCP, which allows sanctions for discovery violations, does not authorize sanctions for the failure to supplement discovery responses in this case.Â  We disagree.Â  SCDOCâ€™s complaint that it simply failed to â€œsupplementâ€ a previous request has no factual basis.Â  Pursuant to an earlier motion to compel, there was a standing order that SCDOC â€œpromptly comply with discovery or [be] subject to sanctions.â€ Â Rule 37(b) expressly provides for an award of sanctions for a partyâ€™s failure to obey a discovery order.[2] Â Because SCDOC failed to fully comply with discovery as ordered, sanctions were authorized under Rule 37.Â 

SCDOCâ€™s remaining issues are without merit and we dispose of them pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  Grant v. South Carolina Coastal Council, 319 S.C. 348, 461 S.E.2d 388 (1995) (procedural due process claim raised for the first time on appeal is not preserved); State v. 192 Coin-Operated Video Game Machines, 338 S.C. 176, 525 S.E.2d 872 (2000) (appellant has the burden to provide an adequate record for review).
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Michael G. Nettles, concur.

[1] Counsel for SCDOC was not aware that the documents had not been produced.
 
[2] This rule provides in pertinent part:
(b) Failure to Comply With Order.
. . . .
(2) Sanctions by Court in Which Action Is Pending.Â  If a party or an officer, director, or managing agent of a party . . . fails to obey an order to provide or permit discovery . . . the court in which the action is pending may make such orders in regard to the failure as are just, and among others the following:
. . . .
require the party failing to obey the order or the attorney advising him or both toÂ  pay the reasonable expenses, including attorneyâ€™s fees, caused by the failure, unless the court finds that the failure was substantially justified or that other circumstances make an award of expenses unjust.

title: In the Matter of Douglas M. Schmidt
description: In this opinion, the Court publicly reprimands Douglas Schmidt.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of Douglas M. Schmidt, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26356
Submitted June 12, 2007 - Filed Â July 9, 2007
PUBLIC REPRIMAND


	
		
			
				Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Senior Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				Douglas M. Schmidt, of Graniteville and New Orleans, 
				pro se.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a letter of caution, a confidential admonition, or a public reprimand. We accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand. The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Respondent is licensed to practice law in South Carolina and Louisiana.Â  Until January 2005, respondent operated a law office in Louisiana only.Â  However, following the train derailment in Graniteville, South Carolina in January 2005, respondent opened a law office in Graniteville.Â  
 
Advertisements
In January 2005, respondent published several advertisements in the Aiken Standard newspaper in order to solicit clients as a result of the train accident.Â  In two of these advertisements, respondent failed to disclose the location, by city or town, where he principally practiced law.Â  Respondent also posted a billboard in Graniteville using a form of the word â€œspecialist,â€ when in fact respondent is not a specialist certified by this Court.[1]Â   
Solicitation Letters
On February 8, 2005, respondent sent a solicitation letter (Letter #1) to residents in and around Graniteville, in which respondent referred to himself as a â€œneighborhood attorneyâ€ and included his photograph.Â  Letter #1 stated his staff â€œwill review your claim to see if you are entitled to damagesâ€ and stated he was able to â€œachieve the best legal results possible.â€Â  Respondent failed to disclose that he principally practiced law in Louisiana, did not disclose how he obtained the information prompting the communication, included a form of the word â€œexpert,â€ and provided an incorrect address and telephone number for the Commission on Lawyer Conduct (the Commission).Â  Respondent did not file a copy of Letter #1 with the Commission and did not pay the required filing fee within ten days of mailing the letter.Â  
 
On February 18, 2005, respondent sent another solicitation letter (Letter #2) to residents in and around Graniteville.Â  Letter #2 was similar, but not identical to Letter #1, in that respondent removed his photograph and the word â€œexpertise.â€Â  Although respondent filed a copy of Letter #2 with the Commission, he failed to provide a list of persons to whom the letter was sent.Â  
 
On March 3, 2005, respondent sent a third solicitation letter (Letter #3) to residents in and around Graniteville, in which he used the phrase â€œexperts in law.â€Â  Respondent failed to file a copy with the Commission, pay the filing fee, or provide a list of persons to whom it was sent within ten days of mailing Letter #3.Â  On March 22, 2005, respondent attempted to file Letter #3 with the Commission, but failed to include a list of persons to whom it was mailed.Â  
 
By letter dated March 7, 2005, ODC notified respondent of a complaint filed against him as a result of the solicitation letters and requested a response within fifteen days.Â  Respondent failed to respond.[2]Â   
Client Letter
On June 16, 2005, respondent sent a letter to his clients regarding a proposed settlement.Â  In the letter, respondent stated he was â€œpicking up an average of an additional 25 clients a day,â€ when, in fact, he was only adding between one and six clients per day.Â  Although respondent believed the statement to be true, he did not verify this statement before including it in the letter.Â  
 
LAW
Respondent admits his conduct constitutes grounds for discipline under Rule 413, RLDE, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers). Â In addition, respondent admits he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR: Rule 7.1(a) (lawyer shall not make false, misleading, deceptive or unfair communications about the lawyer or his services); Rule 7.1(b) (lawyer shall not make communications that are likely to create an unjustified expectation about results the lawyer can achieve); Rule 7.1(c) (lawyer shall not compare his or her services with other lawyersâ€™ services); Rule 7.2(i) (all advertisements shall disclose the geographic location, by city or town, of the office in which the lawyer principally practices law); Rule 7.3(c) (every written or recorded communication subject to this Rule must comply with filing requirements); Rule 7.3(g) (any written communication prompted by a specific occurrence involving or affecting the intended recipient of the communication shall disclose how the lawyer obtained the information prompting the communication); Rule 7.4(b) (lawyer shall not include any form of the words â€œexpertâ€ or â€œspecialistâ€ in advertisements); Rule 8.1(b) (lawyer shall not knowingly fail to respond to lawful demand for information from disciplinary authority).
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.Â  
 
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., not participating.

[1] Respondent taped over the word upon discovery of the error.
[2] Respondent ultimately responded to the complaint following notice of a full investigation.Â

title: Gadson v. ECO Services
description: The Court held the Court of Appeals erred in affirming the trial courtâ€™s denial of Petitionerâ€™s motion for a directed verdict because Respondent failed to submit any evidence establishing the necessary elements of negligent entrustment.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Starr Gadson, by her Guardian ad Litem, Kathy Gadson, Respondent,
				v.
				ECO Services of South Carolina, Inc., and Joseph Jenkins, of whom Joseph Jenkins, is, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Jasper County
Â Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26357
Heard May 2, 2007 - Filed July 16, 2007Â Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Joseph R. Weston, of Weston Law Firm, of Mt. Pleasant, for Petitioner.
				Daniel E. Henderson, of Peters, Murdaugh, Parker, Eltzroth & Detrick, PA, of Ridgeland, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE BURNETT: Â We granted a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision in Gadson v. ECO Services of South Carolina, Op. No. 2005-UP-130 (S.C. Ct. App. filed February 18, 2005).Â  Joseph Jenkins (Petitioner) contends the Court of Appeals erred in affirming the trial courtâ€™s denial of his motions for directed verdict and judgment notwithstanding the verdict (JNOV).Â  We reverse.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Petitioner was employed by ECO Services of South Carolina, Inc. (ECO), a solid waste contractor.Â  On August 6, 1997, instead of returning ECOâ€™s vehicle to the Hilton Head office, Petitioner drove the vehicle to Hardeeville where he picked up several passengers, including Starr Gadson (Respondent) and his cousin, John Jenkins, and drove them to McDonaldâ€™s.Â  Petitioner then drove them to a store where John purchased one or two wine coolers.Â  John shared the wine coolers with another passenger.Â 
 
Petitioner drove them to Purrysburg Landing, where they talked for about an hour.Â  On the way back to Hardeeville, John drove the vehicle.Â  John reached a speed of 80 miles per hour before losing control of the vehicle.Â  Several passengers, including Respondent, were thrown from the vehicle and sustained injuries.Â 
 
Respondent filed an action against ECO and Petitioner, alleging negligence and negligent entrustment.Â  Neither Petitioner nor John appeared at trial.Â  However, Petitioner did move for a directed verdict.Â  The jury returned a verdict against all three defendants, finding: (1) ECO entrusted the vehicle to Petitioner; (2) ECO was negligent in entrusting the vehicle to Petitioner; (3) ECOâ€™s negligence proximately caused Respondentâ€™s injuries; (4) John was driving the vehicle at the time of the accident and was doing so negligently; (5) Johnâ€™s negligence proximately caused Respondentâ€™s injuries; (6) Petitioner was not driving the vehicle at the time of the accident; and (7) Petitioner was negligent in entrusting the vehicle to John.Â  The jury awarded Respondent $50,000 in actual damages.
Both ECO and Petitioner moved for JNOV and a new trial based on juror misconduct.Â  The trial court dismissed both motions finding they were not timely filed.Â  The Court of Appeals remanded and the trial court considered and denied the motions.Â  ECO and Petitioner appealed.Â  Based on the definition of negligent entrustment as provided by the Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§ 308 (1965), the Court of Appeals affirmed as to Petitioner and reversed as to ECO.Â  Gadson v. ECO Services of S.C., Op. No. 2005-UP-130 (S.C. Ct. App. filed February 18, 2005).Â  Specifically, the Court of Appeals considered Petitionerâ€™s driving record and work history and found ECO neither knew nor should have known Petitioner intended or was likely to use the truck in such a manner as to create an unreasonable risk of harm to others.Â  As for Petitioner, the Court of Appeals found he knew or should have known Johnâ€™s use of the vehicle was likely to cause harm considering their familial relationship and the fact John consumed alcohol before driving.Â  
 
ISSUE 


	Did the Court of Appeals err in affirming the trial courtâ€™s denial of Petitionerâ€™s motions for directed verdict and JNOV and in finding Petitioner negligently entrusted the vehicle to John Jenkins?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the denial of a motion for directed verdict or JNOV, this Court applies the same standard as the trial court.Â  Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 602 S.E.2d 772 (2004). Â The Court is required to view the evidence and inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Sabb v. S.C. State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 567 S.E.2d 231 (2002).Â  The motions should be denied when either the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt.Â  McMillan v. Oconee Memâ€™l Hosp., Inc., 367 S.C. 559, 626 S.E.2d 884 (2006).Â  An appellate court will only reverse the lower courtâ€™s ruling when there is no evidence to support the ruling or when the ruling is controlled by an error of law. Â Steinke v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing and Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 520 S.E.2d 142 (1999). 
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Petitioner argues the Court of Appeals erred in affirming the trial courtâ€™s denial of his motions for directed verdict and JNOV and in finding he negligently entrusted the vehicle to John Jenkins.Â  Specifically, Petitioner argues there is no evidence from which a jury could have reasonably concluded he knew or had reason to know John was likely to use the vehicle in a manner involving unreasonable risk of physical harm to himself or others.Â 
 
to our case law, the elements of negligent entrustment are: (1) knowledge of or knowledge imputable to the owner that the driver was either addicted to intoxicants or had the habit of drinking; (2) the owner knew or had imputable knowledge that the driver was likely to drive while intoxicated; and (3) under these circumstances, the entrustment of a vehicle by the owner to such a driver.Â  Jackson v. Price, 288 S.C. 377, 342 S.E.2d 628 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  However, in determining whether Respondent met her burden of proving the elements of negligent entrustment, the Court of Appeals applied Restatement (Second) of Torts Â§Â§ 308 and 390,[1] which extend liability when the owner knows or had reason to know that such person is likely because of his youth, inexperience, or otherwise, to create an unreasonable risk of physical harm to himself and others.Â  We decline to adopt sections 308 and 390 of the Restatement based on this set of facts, and we analyze this case under the elements of negligent entrustment set forth in Jackson.Â  Â Â 
The Court of Appeals erred in finding Petitioner knew John would cause harm because Petitioner knew John had been drinking alcohol prior to driving the vehicle.Â  Over an hour before driving the vehicle, Petitioner witnessed John purchase and consume wine coolers.Â  It is disputed whether John purchased one or two wine coolers and whether he shared the drinks with another passenger.Â  Petitioner stated in his brief and Respondent testified at trial that John did not appear intoxicated.Â  Furthermore, there was no evidence as to Johnâ€™s drinking habits or his driving record.Â  The sole evidence supporting the claim for negligent entrustment against Petitioner is the fact John had one or two wine coolers prior to driving.Â  Knowledge that a driver has had a drink or two is a far cry from meeting the first element of negligent entrustment that there be knowledge of or knowledge imputable to the owner that the driver was either addicted to intoxicants or had the habit of drinking.
Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Respondents, there was no support for the contention Petitioner, or even Respondent, for that matter, knew John was intoxicated; nor was there evidence Petitioner knew John had a habit of being intoxicated and driving.Â  Evidence John consumed as little as half of a wine cooler[2] an hour before driving the vehicle does not support a finding of negligent entrustment against Petitioner.Â  See, e.g., Greene v. Jenkins, 481 S.E.2d 617 (Ga. Ct. App. 1997) (parents were not liable for entrusting vehicle to son when parents knew son had a couple of drinks, but did not know he was incompetent due to intoxication and when passenger in wrecked vehicle testified she would not have ridden with the son had she believed he was intoxicated); Gibson v. Bruner, 178 A.2d 145 (Pa. 1961) (JNOV granted to father who entrusted truck to son after son had consumed four bottles of beer when there was no evidence son was intoxicated or unable to drive the truck competently).
The Court of Appeals also erred in finding Petitioner knew John would cause harm simply because John was Petitionerâ€™s cousin.Â  The Court of Appeals held, â€œ[Petitioner] was apparently familiar with Johnâ€™s character, because he was Johnâ€™s cousin.â€Â  Gadson v. ECO Services of S.C., Op. No. 2005-UP-130 (S.C. Ct. App. filed February 18, 2005).Â  Respondent presented no evidence Petitioner had any knowledge of Johnâ€™s drinking habits, driving record, or general behavior.Â  Assuming Petitioner was aware of Johnâ€™s character simply because Petitioner and John are cousins was error.Â  
 
Finally, the Court of Appeals erred in finding the jury could have inferred the elements of negligent entrustment had been met when Petitioner failed to testify on his own behalf.Â  The failure of a defendant to testify raises an inference that his testimony, if it had been submitted, would have been unfavorable to his position.Â  See, e.g., Crocker v. Weathers, 240 S.C. 412, 126 S.E. 335 (1962). Â However, Respondent presented no evidence Petitioner knew John would create an unreasonable risk of harm other than evidence Petitioner and John were cousins and John consumed a minimal amount of alcohol before driving.Â  Respondent carried the burden of proof and failed to present any evidence Petitioner negligently entrusted the vehicle to John.Â  See Ross v. Paddy, 340 S.C. 428, 433, 532 S.E.2d 612, 614 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œThe burden of proof is on the plaintiff to establish the negligence of the defendant.â€).Â  Respondent failed to meet her burden of proof and cannot rely on the absence of Petitioner at trial to fill the void of evidence.Â Â  
 
CONCLUSION
The Court of Appeals erred in affirming the trial courtâ€™s denial of Petitionerâ€™s motion for a directed verdict because Respondent failed to submit any evidence establishing the necessary elements of negligent entrustment.Â 
 
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, J., and Acting Justice J. Cordell Maddox, concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurring in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I agree with the majority that petitionerâ€™s JNOV motion should have been granted, but write separately because I believe we should adopt Restatement (Second) of Torts, Â§Â§ 308 and 390 as alternative methods of proving negligent entrustment.Â  I fear that our current formulation would not admit of liability where a person permitted an individual to drive an automobile knowing that the driver was intoxicated, but where there was no evidence the supplier knew the driver was a habitual drinker or addicted to alcohol.Â  In my view, adoption of sections 308 and 390 would eliminate this loophole.Â  That said, I agree that even under these formulations, there is no evidence that petitioner knew or should have known that John Jenkins was likely to operate the vehicle in a manner which created an unreasonable risk of harm.Â  I therefore concur in the decision to reverse and remand the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision affirming the trial courtâ€™s denial of petitionerâ€™s JNOV motion.Â Â 
 

[1] Section 308 provides:
It is negligence to permit a third person to use a thing or to engage in an activity which is under the control of the actor, if the actor knows or should know that such person intends or is likely to use the thing or to conduct himself in the activity in such a manner as to create an unreasonable risk of harm to others.
Section 390 provides:
One who supplies directly or through a third person a chattel for the use of another whom the supplier knows or has reason to know to be likely because of his youth, inexperience, or otherwise, to use it in a manner involving unreasonable risk of physical harm to himself and others whom the supplier should expect to share in or be endangered by its use, is subject to liability for physical harm resulting to them.
[2] Â Respondent testified John split the wine cooler with another passenger.Â

title: New York Times Co. v. Spartanburg County School District No. 7
description: The Court affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s interpretation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§  30-4-40(a)(13), which is a FOIA statute concerning information to be disclosed during a public employerâ€™s search to fill an employment position.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The New York Times Co., d/b/a The Spartanburg Herald-Journal, and Bob Dalton, Respondents,
				v.
				Spartanburg County School District No. 7, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Spartanburg County
Â Roger L. Couch, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26358
Heard June 20, 2007 - Filed July 16, 2007Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Kenneth E. Darr and Carlos C. Johnson, both of Lyles, Darr & Clark, of Spartanburg, for Appellant.
				Jay Bender, of Baker, Ravenel & Bender, of Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  This is an appeal from an order granting injunctive relief and attorneyâ€™s fees under the Freedom of Information Act (â€œFOIAâ€) to plaintiffs New York Times Co., d/b/a The Spartanburg Herald-Journal, and Bob Dalton, city editor for the paper (collectively, â€œrespondentsâ€).Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In 2003, while Spartanburg County School District No. 7 (â€œappellantâ€) was searching for a school superintendent, respondents transmitted a FOIA request seeking material relative to appellantâ€™s search.Â  Specifically, respondents requested, â€œ[A]ccess to all materials gathered by the Spartanburg School District No. 7 Trustees regardless of form, relating to not fewer than the final three applicants considered for the District No. 7 superintendentâ€™s position.â€[1]Â  
 
Appellant described its superintendent selection process as beginning with a group of approximately thirty applicants.Â  That group was narrowed to five â€œsemi-finalists,â€ out of which two â€œfinalistsâ€ were selected.Â  The district had assured the five semi-finalists that only the identities of the finalists would be revealed.Â  As a result, appellant only offered to make available material relating to the two individuals considered to be â€œfinalists.â€Â 
 
Respondents filed a complaint shortly thereafter, seeking a declaratory judgment that appellant violated S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-40(a)(13) and injunctive relief restraining the district from withholding further information related to the superintendent search.Â 
 
After a non-jury trial, the circuit court found that appellant had violated Â§ 30-4-40(a)(13), ordered the disclosure of additional information, and awarded attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to respondents.
ISSUES

	1.  Did appellant violate Â§ 30-4-40(a)(13) by disclosing information relating to only the two applicants it deemed to be the final applicants?
	2.  Did the circuit court err by awarding attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to respondents, where appellant acted in good faith based on its reasonable understanding of the statute?

ANALYSIS
In a case raising a novel question regarding the interpretation of a statute, the appellate court is free to decide the question with no particular deference to the lower court. Â Sloan v. South Carolina Bd. of Physical Therapy Examiners, 370 S.C. 452, 466, 636 S.E.2d 598, 605 (2006). Â We cannot construe a statute without regard to its plain and ordinary meaning, and this Court may not resort to subtle or forced construction in an attempt to limit or expand a statuteâ€™s scope. Â City of Columbia v. Am. Civ. Liberties Union of South Carolina, Inc., 323 S.C. 384, 388, 475 S.E.2d 747, 749 (1996).
In interpreting a statute, our primary purpose is to ascertain the intent of the legislature.Â  Beattie v. Aiken County Dept. of Soc. Serv., 319 S.C. 449, 452, 462 S.E.2d 276, 278 (1995).Â  â€œA statute as a whole must receive a practical, reasonable, and fair interpretation consonant with the purpose, design, and policy of the lawmakers.â€ Â Id. (citing Browning v. Hartvigsen, 307 S.C. 122, 125, 414 S.E.2d 115, 117 (1992)).
FOIA is remedial in nature and should be liberally construed to carry out the purpose mandated by the legislature.Â  Quality Towing, Inc. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 345 S.C. 156, 161, 547 S.E.2d 862, 864-865 (2001).Â  FOIA must be construed so as to make it possible for citizens to learn and report fully the activities of public officials.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-15 (Supp. 2007).
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-40(a)(13), which exempts from mandatory disclosure certain material gathered in the search to fill a public employment position, provides:

	(a) A public body may but is not required to exempt from disclosure the following information:
	â€¦.
	(13) All materials, regardless of form, gathered by a public body during a search to fill an employment position, 
	except that materials relating to not fewer than the final three applicants under consideration for a position must be made available for public inspection and copying.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-40(a)(13) (emphasis added).Â  The circuit court determined that this provision required disclosure of material relating to applicants in the pool from which the employment selection was made, provided that pool contained not fewer than three people.Â  
 
Appellant contends that Â§ 30-4-40(a)(13) only mandates disclosure of those applicants deemed by the public body to be the â€œfinalâ€ applicants, even if that number is fewer than three.Â  We disagree.
The statutory language requiring disclosure of materials relating to â€œnot fewer than the final three applicantsâ€ requires the public body to disclose the final pool of applicants comprised of at least three people.Â  We do not agree with appellant that only those applicants deemed by the agency to be â€œfinalistsâ€ are subject to disclosure. Â According to the plain language of the statute, disclosure is limited to the final pool consisting of not fewer than three applicants.Â 
 
Application of the statute in this case requires that disclosure be limited to the final group numbering more than two- i.e., the five semi-finalists, not the entire group of thirty applicants.Â  The term â€œfinalâ€ in Â§ 30-4-40(a)(13) refers to the last group of applicants, with at least three members, from which the employment selection is made.
Appellant also argues that Â§ 30-4-40(a)(13), as interpreted by the circuit court, has the absurd effect of forcing public employers to name three finalists even though there may only be two qualified candidates.Â  We disagree.Â 
 
The fact that a public employer has to disclose information regarding an employment search does not in any way force the employer to officially name three finalists.Â  The statute simply requires a public employer to disclose material relating to a larger group of applicants if it chooses to name one or two â€œfinalists.â€Â  Construing Â§ 30-4-40(a)(13) as urged by appellant would allow public employers to avoid disclosure by naming only one or two â€œfinalists.â€Â  We will reject a statutory interpretation that leads to a result so plainly absurd that it could not have been intended by the legislature or would defeat the plain legislative intention. Â Kiriakides v. United Artists Commun., Inc., 312 S.C. 271, 275, 440 S.E.2d 364, 366 (1994). Â Our interpretation of Â§ 30-4-40(a)(13) comports with the plain language of the statute and promotes the purpose of FOIA.
Appellant also argues that the circuit court abused its discretion by awarding attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to respondents.Â  We disagree.
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 30-4-100(b) (Supp. 2007) allows for an award of attorneyâ€™s fees where the party seeking relief prevails in whole or in part.Â  After the circuit court granted relief to respondents, it directed respondents to submit material in support of their claim for attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.Â  Appellant does not challenge the amount of the award nor the material submitted in support of the award.
Appellant contends that if the Court finds it violated Â§ 30-4-40(a)(13), attorneyâ€™s fees are not proper because appellant acted in good faith based on its reasonable understanding of that section.Â  We previously rejected the same argument in Socy. of Prof. Journalists v. Sexton, 283 S.C. 563, 324 S.E.2d 313 (1984).Â  No good faith exception exists for an award of attorneyâ€™s fees under FOIA.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees and costs to respondents pursuant to Â§ 30-4-100(b).
CONCLUSION
We hold that appellant violated FOIA by not disclosing material relating to the applicants in the group of five.Â  Furthermore, the circuit court did not abuse its discretion by awarding attorneyâ€™s fees to respondents.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s order is
 
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.

description: This is a disciplinary opinion in which the Court definitely suspended an attorney for one year.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter
          of William F. â€œTroupâ€ Partridge, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26359
  Submitted June 25, 2007 - Filed July 18,
  2007Â Â   

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
        Desa Ballard, of West Columbia, for respondent.Â  
		 
      
    
  


PER
  CURIAM:Â Â  In this
  attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel
  (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule
  21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and
  consents to a definite suspension from the practice of law of up to one (1) year.Â 
  He requests the suspension be made retroactive to the date of his November 3,
  2006 interim suspension.Â  In the Matter of PartridgeÂ¸ 371
  S.C. 20, 637 S.E.2d 309 (2006).Â  We accept the
  agreement and impose a one year suspension.Â  The suspension shall not be made
  retroactive to the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  The facts, as set
  forth in the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Respondent was admitted to the South
  Carolina Bar in 2003.Â  Initially, he was employed as a law clerk to Circuit Court
  Judge Wyatt Saunders.Â  Thereafter, he was employed by the South Carolina
  Attorney Generalâ€™s Office.Â   
During respondentâ€™s employment
  with the Attorney Generalâ€™s Office, Matthew Boland (Boland), a family friend, asked
  respondent to provide assistance in connection with a ticket issued in Newberry County. Â The ticket charged Boland with speeding 85 mph in a 55 mph zone, a 6
  point violation.Â  The ticket was returnable before Newberry County Magistrate Mark
  English.[1]Â   
Respondent suggested Boland and/or
  Bolandâ€™s father contact respondentâ€™s father, a lawyer who practiced law in Newberry County. Â Respondent believed that Boland and/or Bolandâ€™s father contacted
  respondentâ€™s father but he had no actual knowledge of whether or not his own
  father assisted Boland until later.Â   
It is now known that
  respondentâ€™s father had a conversation with his son-in-law, Newberry County
  Magistrate Joseph Beckham,[2] concerning the Boland ticket.Â  Magistrate Beckham then had a conversation with
  the officer who issued Bolandâ€™s ticket.Â  As a result, the officer agreed to
  mark the ticket â€œnot guilty.â€Â   
Thereafter, Magistrate English
  heard the case against Boland.Â  Boland did not appear at the hearing and the
  officer made no comment to Magistrate English when the case was called for
  trial.Â  Magistrate English marked the ticket â€œ425â€ and â€œNRVCâ€ and sent it to
  the South Carolina Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) for processing as a
  â€œguilty/defendant did not appear or paid [sic] fineâ€ ticket case.Â  The officer,
  however, checked the â€œappearedâ€ box (which was not true) and the â€œnot guiltyâ€
  box on the ticket.Â   
In June 2004, Bolandâ€™s father
  contacted respondent.Â  He told respondent he understood that Boland had been
  found not guilty, but that Boland had received notice from the DMV that his
  driverâ€™s license was going to be suspended because of the conviction.Â   
Respondent personally visited
  the Magistrateâ€™s Office and obtained a copy of the ticket in issue.Â  He
  discovered there was a discrepancy in the records.Â  One ticket contained marks
  indicating Boland had appeared for trial and was found guilty and another
  reflected Boland had been found not guilty.Â   
Respondent telephoned Magistrate
  English and inquired how Boland could address the discrepancy in the records.Â 
  Respondent states he inquired if a petition for a writ of mandamus was the
  proper procedure for seeking to clarify the records concerning the ticket.Â  Magistrate
  English informed ODC, however, that respondent threatened to file a petition
  for a writ of mandamus to correct the ticket.Â  Other than the statements of
  Magistrate English and respondent, there is no evidence to substantiate either
  version of events.Â   
Thereafter, respondent and Judge
  Saunders discussed the discrepancy in the tickets over the telephone.Â 
  Initially, respondent told ODC he did not have a telephone conversation with
  Judge Saunders, but later acknowledged that he did have such a conversation.Â Â  Â 
Respondent believes he provided
  a copy of the ticket to his father.Â  However, he may have given the ticket to
  Boland or Bolandâ€™s father.
At approximately 1:00 p.m. on
  June 11, 2004, Boland came to respondentâ€™s office in Columbia to have his
  affidavit notarized.Â  Respondent arranged for a co-worker to notarize the
  affidavit.Â  Respondent represents that, at the time, he was unaware that his father
  had prepared pleadings,[3] including an affidavit, for Boland to file pro se.Â  
 
On June 11, 2004, the pleadings
  were presented by someone to Judge Saunders for his signature.[4]Â  The same day, Judge Saunders signed
  the proposed order requiring Magistrate English to appear before him the next
  business day for purposes of correcting the error in the records. Â The same
  day, respondent visited Judge Saundersâ€™ chambers and, at the judgeâ€™s request,
  arranged to have the pleadings served on Magistrate English.Â   
Respondent called the Sheriff of
  Newberry County regarding service, then delivered the pleadings to a sheriffâ€™s
  deputy for service on Magistrate English.Â  The Sheriff states respondent
  advised him that the Attorney General wanted the papers served.Â  Respondent
  denies having made this assertion.Â  Other than the statements of the Sheriff
  and respondent, there is no evidence to substantiate either version of the
  events.Â   
At the hearing held before Judge
  Saunders, Boland, pro se, appeared with his father.Â  Neither
  respondent nor his father appeared at the hearing.Â  After Judge Saunders
  suggested that Magistrate English, Boland, and Bolandâ€™s father discuss the
  matter, Magistrate English changed the ticket to â€œnot guilty.â€Â   
In April 2005, ODC was
  conducting investigations related to Magistrates English and Beckham.Â 
  Respondent was asked to voluntarily appear before ODC to give testimony
  detailing his knowledge of Bolandâ€™s ticket.Â   
On April 14, 2005, respondent
  voluntarily appeared before Disciplinary Counsel.Â  He was sworn as a witness
  and gave testimony under oath.Â  Respondent testified he did not know who had
  prepared the pleadings which were presented to and signed by Judge Saunders.Â  Disciplinary
  Counsel asserts respondent did know who had prepared the pleadings, but
  intentionally withheld that information from ODC.Â  Respondent claims he did not
  know his father had prepared the pleadings until he discussed the matter with
  his father after the examination.Â  However, respondent acknowledges he was not
  fully forthcoming about his knowledge of Bolandâ€™s ticket when he was examined
  under oath and that he testified he did not know the answers to certain
  questions when, in fact, he did.Â   
When he was examined under oath
  by Disciplinary Counsel, respondent voluntarily produced certain documents he
  had in his possession related to Bolandâ€™s ticket.Â  One document provided to ODC
  (the letter from DMV to Boland requiring him to surrender his driverâ€™s license)
  contained handwriting which had been obliterated using â€œwhite out.â€Â  In
  response to questions from ODC, respondent represented he did not know who had
  placed the â€œwhite outâ€ on the document.Â  The information obliterated by the
  â€œwhite outâ€ was facsimile information from the person who faxed the DMV letter
  to respondent and respondentâ€™s facsimile number at the Attorney Generalâ€™s
  Office which had been written on the document by its sender.Â Â   
According to respondent, after
  providing his testimony in April, he spoke with his father and learned his
  father had prepared the pleadings.Â  Respondent wrote ODC and requested an
  opportunity to correct certain answers he had given in his April examination.Â  
 
On May 24, 2005, respondent was
  again sworn and examined under oath.Â  Some of the answers he gave to the
  questions by ODC conflicted with answers given in the April 2005 examination.Â 
  Respondent did, however, disclose that his father had prepared the pleadings
  for Boland.Â Â   
At the May 2005 interview,
  respondent falsely stated he did not know until the pleadings had been served
  that they related to Boland and the ticket.Â  However, at the previous April
  interview, respondent had testified he was surprised to see that the pleadings given
  to him by Judge Saunders on June 11, 2004 for filing and service related to
  Boland and the ticket.Â  Further, respondentâ€™s father had stated under oath that
  he was present during respondentâ€™s telephone call to the Newberry County
  Sheriff to make arrangements for effecting service of the pleadings on
  Magistrate English and saw respondent holding the pleadings in his hand.Â 
  Respondent acknowledges that he was aware when he filed the pleadings with the
  clerk and delivered them to a deputy sheriff (who came to his fatherâ€™s house to
  pick up the pleadings) that they were related to Boland and the ticket. Â 
As part of a judicial grievance
  matter, Magistrate Beckham was examined under oath on May 26, 2005, in Columbia.Â  After the examination, Magistrate Beckham met respondent at his home.[5]Â  Respondentâ€™s father happened by
  respondentâ€™s house.Â  Respondent, his father, and Magistrate Beckham discussed
  the events related to Bolandâ€™s ticket.Â  Based on statements subsequently made
  by respondentâ€™s now estranged wife, ODC alleged respondent sought to instruct
  his father and Magistrate Beckham how to answer questions related to Bolandâ€™s
  ticket so their explanations would be consistent.Â  Respondent represents that
  the conversation began with Magistrate Beckham reciting what he recalled of the
  examination by ODC earlier that day, which led to a discussion among respondent,
  his father, and Magistrate Beckham as to what each of them recalled about the
  matter.Â   
Respondent represents that he
  did not instruct anyone on how to answer questions and that he did not undertake
  any effort to make the stories consistent.Â  Respondent points out that he, his
  father, and Magistrate Beckham had already testified under oath before ODC so
  all they were doing was comparing experiences.Â  In sworn testimony before ODC,
  respondent stated he did not recall a â€œmeetingâ€ to discuss the ticket, but now
  recalls there was such a meeting.Â  ODC believes that the meeting was a chance
  get together rather than a scheduled meeting.Â   

LAW
Respondent admits that by his misconduct
  he has violated the following Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â 
  Rule 1.2(d) (lawyer shall not counsel client to engage in or assist client in
  conduct lawyer knows is criminal or fraudulent); Rule 1.7(a) (lawyer shall not
  represent client if representation of that client will be directly adverse to
  another client); Rule 1.11(d) (lawyer who serves as public employee shall not
  violate Rule 1.7, RPC); Rule 3.3(a) (lawyer shall not knowingly make false
  statement of material fact to a tribunal); Rule 3.3(d) (in ex parte proceeding, lawyer shall inform tribunal of all material facts which will
  enable tribunal to make an informed decision); Rule 3.5(a) (lawyer shall not
  seek to influence a judge by means prohibited by law); Rule 8.1(a) (lawyer
  shall not knowingly make false statement of material fact in connection with a
  disciplinary matter); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to
  violate the Rules of Professional Conduct or knowingly assist or induce another
  to do so); Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to engage in
  conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation); Rule 8.4(e) (it
  is professional misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial
  to the administration of justice); and Rule 8.4(g) (it is professional
  misconduct for lawyer to knowingly assist a judge in conduct that is a
  violation of the applicable rules of judicial conduct or other law).Â  In
  addition, respondent admits that his actions constitute grounds for discipline
  under the following provisions of Rule 7, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR:Â  Rule 7(a)(1)
  (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to violate the Rules of
  Professional Conduct) and Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be a ground for discipline for
  a lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice
  or to bring the courts or the legal profession into disrepute).
CONCLUSION
We
  accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and suspend respondent from the
  practice of law for one (1) year.Â  The suspension shall not be retroactive to
  the date of respondentâ€™s interim suspension.Â  Within fifteen days of the filing
  of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit demonstrating he has
  complied with the requirements of Rule 30 of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary
  Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE
  SUSPENSION.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.
  

[1] The handling of the traffic ticket has
  previously been the subject of two judicial disciplinary opinions.Â  See In
    the Matter of English, 367 S.C. 297, 625 S.E.2d 919 (2006); In the
      Matter of Beckham, 365 S.C. 637, 620 S.E.2d 69 (2005).
[2] Respondentâ€™s sister is married to Magistrate
  Beckham.Â   
[3] The pleadings included a proposed rule to show
  cause order requiring Magistrate English to appear before Judge Saunders.Â  
 
[4] According to the Agreement, evidence is inconclusive
  as to how the pleadings reached Judge Saunders.Â   
[5] At that time, respondent and this wife,
  Magistrate Beckhamâ€™s sister, resided in Columbia. Â Â Â Â

title: Cohenâ€™s Drywall v. Sea Spray Homes
description: This appeal arises out of the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of an action to enforce a mechanicsâ€™ lien on the basis that the action was not timely filed.  We reverse.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Cohenâ€™s Drywall Co. Inc., 
				Appellant,
				v.
				Sea Spray Homes, LLC, Robin C. Wahler, Susan C. Wahler, and Plantation Federal Bank, 
				Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal from Georgetown County
Â Benjamin H. Culbertson, Master-in-Equity
Opinion No. 26360
Heard June 5, 2007 - Filed July 23, 2007Â Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Steven L. Smith, of Smith & Koontz, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Joe M. Crosby, of Crosby Law Firm, of Georgetown, for Respondents.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: This appeal arises out of the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of an action to enforce a mechanicsâ€™ lien on the basis that the action was not timely filed.Â  We reverse.
Factual / Procedural Background
Appellant Cohenâ€™s Drywall Co., Inc. (â€œAppellantâ€) performed work on and provided materials for the construction of a residence owned by Respondents Robin C. Wahler and Susan Wahler (â€œRespondentsâ€).Â  In April 2004, after completing work on the residence, Appellant properly filed a mechanicsâ€™ lien against the Respondentsâ€™ property.Â  Shortly after Appellant filed the mechanicsâ€™ lien, Respondents posted a cash bond to release the property from the mechanicsâ€™ lien with the Georgetown County Clerk of Court and recorded the release of the lien with the Georgetown County Register of Deeds Office.
Approximately four months after Respondents posted the cash bond to release the real property from the lien, Appellant brought an action to enforce the mechanicsâ€™ lien.Â  Appellant named the real property as the subject of the enforcement action, and Appellant commenced the initial action within the six-month time limit provided in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-120 (2005).Â  Subsequent to the initial filing, Appellant discovered that Respondents had posted a cash bond to release the real property from the lien.Â  Appellant then amended the averments of its complaint to identify the bond as the subject of the enforcement action.Â  This amendment occurred after the expiration of the time limit for bringing an action to enforce the mechanicsâ€™ lien.Â 
 
Respondents filed a motion to dismiss the enforcement action and a motion to release the bond alleging that Appellant failed to bring the action to foreclose the mechanicsâ€™ lien against the bond within the six-month time limit.Â  The trial court granted Respondentsâ€™ motion to dismiss and released the bond from the lien. Â This appeal followed and this Court certified the case from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  Appellant raises the following issue for this Courtâ€™s review:

	Did the trial court err in granting Respondentsâ€™ motion to dismiss the enforcement action and motion to release the cash bond from the mechanicsâ€™ lien?

Standard of Review
The foreclosure of a mechanicsâ€™ lien is an action at law.Â  Butler Contracting, Inc. v. Court Street, LLC, 369 S.C. 121, 127, 631 S.E.2d 252, 256 (2006).Â Â  In an action at law, tried without a jury, an appellate court will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact unless they are wholly unsupported by the evidence or unless it clearly appears the findings are controlled by an error of law.Â  Id. (citing Townes Assocs. Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 86, 221 S.E.2d 773, 775 (1976)).
Law / Analysis
Appellant argues that the trial court erred in granting Respondentsâ€™ motion to dismiss the enforcement action and motion to release the cash bond which secured the mechanicsâ€™ lien.Â  Specifically, Appellant alleges that the trial court erred in interpreting the relevant statutes to require Appellant to commence a separate action against the cash bond to enforce its mechanicsâ€™ lien.Â  Instead, Appellant argues its original enforcement action naming the Respondentsâ€™ real property as the subject of the action is sufficient to secure foreclosure on the bond.Â  We agree.
The procedures for the establishment and enforcement of a mechanicsâ€™ lien are provided by statute.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 29-5-10 et seq. (2005).Â  The Code provides:Â Â Â  
 

	Unless a suit for enforcing the lien is commenced, and notice of pendency of the action is filed, within six months after the person desiring to avail himself thereof ceases to labor on or furnish labor or material for such building or structures, the lien shall be dissolved.Â 
	

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-120.  
Generally, a mechanicsâ€™ lien is enforced against the real property upon which the services were performed or materials provided.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 29-5-10 to -21.Â  However, the Code provides that the property may be released from a mechanicsâ€™ lien under certain circumstances.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-110.Â Â  
 

	At any time after service and filing of the statement required under Â§ 29-5- 90 the owner or any other person having an interest in or lien upon the property involved may secure the discharge of such property from such lien by filing in the office of clerk of court or register of deeds where such lien is filed his written undertaking, in an amount equal to one and one-third times the amount claimed in such statement, secured by the pledge of United States or State of South Carolina securities, by cash or by a surety bond executed by a surety company licensed to do business in this State, and upon the filing of such undertaking so secured the lien shall be discharged and the cash, securities or surety bond deposited shall take the place of the property upon which the lien existed and shall be subject to the lien. . . .Â  Unless suit for enforcement of the lien is commenced as required by Â§ 29-5-120, the undertaking herein required shall be null and void and the principal therein shall have the right to have it canceled and such cash or securities deposited or pledged or surety bond filed shall be released from the lien herein provided.

Id.
As the statute provides, compliance with any number of bond procedures allows a property owner to release his property from the mechanicsâ€™ lien.Â  See also Shelley Constr. Co. v. Sea Garden Homes, Inc., 287 S.C. 24, 27, 336 S.E.2d 488, 490 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  This allows â€œthe owner to convey or encumber the property free and clear of the mechanicsâ€™ lien.â€Â  Id.Â  
 
All of the statutory requirements for the enforcement of a mechanicsâ€™ lien must be strictly followed.Â  Butler Contracting, Inc., 369 S.C. at 130, 631 S.E.2d at 257.Â  The failure to adhere to the requirements of the statutes will result in the dissolution of the lien, although such failure does not preclude an action on the debt.Â  Shelley Constr. Co., 287 S.C. at 27, 336 S.E.2d at 490.Â  
 
Turning to our analysis of the question presented in this case, in order to be properly filed, the relevant statutes require only that a suit for enforcement of the mechanicsâ€™ lien be commenced within six months of the last provision of services or materials for the construction of the building.Â  Â Tellingly, neither statute requires a lien holder to name a substituted cash bond or other undertaking as the subject of the enforcement action.Â  See Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992) (noting that in construing a statute, its words must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation).Â  In the absence of such a requirement, we interpret Â§ 29-5-110 as an instructional mechanism to the court directing that a judgment on a foreclosed mechanicsâ€™ lien be executed against a cash bond or other secured undertaking if one has been substituted in accordance with the statutory requirements.Â  To reach a contrary interpretation would impose a continuing record-checking obligation on the holder of the mechanicsâ€™ lien that the statutes do not contemplate. 
 
In the instant case, Appellant commenced the enforcement action well before the expiration of the statutory time limit.Â  Â We find that the statutes do not require the Appellant to bring the enforcement action against the cash bond.Â  Therefore, Appellantâ€™s amendment of the complaint was unnecessary and Appellant timely commenced the action to enforce the mechanicsâ€™ lien. Â Â 
Accordingly, we hold that the trial court erred in granting Respondentsâ€™ motion to dismiss Appellantâ€™s enforcement action and motion to release the cash bond. Â Â Â 
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision.Â  We direct that the cash bond be reposted, and we remand the case for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.
 
MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

title: In the Matter of Cletus K. Okpalaeke
description: This is an attorney disciplinary matter involving multiple instances of misconduct.  Ultimately, the Court ordered that Respondent be disbarred from the practice of law.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of Cletus K. Okpalaeke, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26361
Submitted June 20, 2007 - Filed July 23, 2007 

DISBARRED


	
		
			
				Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Barbara M. Seymour, Senior Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				Cletus K. Okpalaeke, of Columbia, pro se.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  This is an attorney disciplinary matter.Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (â€œODCâ€) brought formal charges against Respondent Cletus K. Okpalaeke based upon several alleged acts of misconduct.Â  The panel of the Commission on Lawyer Conduct (â€œthe Panelâ€) found that Respondent committed numerous acts of misconduct and recommended that Respondent be disbarred from the practice of law.Â  Neither ODC nor Respondent, who is in default, objected to the Panelâ€™s findings or recommendation.Â  We accept the Panelâ€™s report, and we hereby disbar Respondent from the practice of law.

Factual/Procedural Background
In 2005, ODC formally charged Respondent with multiple ethical violations arising out of several otherwise unrelated events.Â  The record indicates that despite attempted service by certified mail and by agents of the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division, Respondent was never served with these formal charges.Â  The record also indicates that Respondent has not filed an answer to these charges.Â  In early 2006, upon request from ODC, the Panel ordered that Respondent be held in default.[1]
The formal charges in this matter describe approximately nine different instances of misconduct.Â  Briefly summarized, these instances include:
A. The Driversâ€™ License and Office Management Matters
Respondent attended law school in Minnesota and graduated in 1993.Â  Respondent moved to South Carolina in 1996, and Respondent was sworn in to the practice of law in South Carolina July 23, 1997.[2]Â  When Respondent moved to South Carolina, he had a valid Minnesota driversâ€™ license.Â  Respondent did not obtain a South Carolina driversâ€™ license after his relocation.Â  Instead, Respondent drove using his Minnesota license until it expired.Â  Respondent then drove without a valid license until he was arrested in 1999 for driving under the influence of alcohol and for driving without a valid license.Â  Respondent pled guilty to these charges.
Respondentâ€™s law office was a solo practice, and Respondent rented office space from a friend, Doe.Â  Respondent allowed Doe, a non-lawyer, to manage major aspects of Respondentâ€™s law practice.Â  Respondent gave Doe signatory authority on Respondentâ€™s operating and trust accounts, and Respondent also gave Doe supervisory authority over the office while Respondent was out of the country.
According to ODC, Respondent failed to deposit client funds into his trust account and commingled his funds with client funds when he processed settlements through his operating account.Â  Respondent also allowed Doe to handle client settlements without the supervision of an attorney and Respondent disbursed client settlement funds from his operating account in the form of checks made payable to â€œcash.â€Â  According to ODC, eleven checks drawn on Respondentâ€™s operating/trust account were returned for insufficient funds during a six month period in 2000.Â  During that same period, ODC alleged that the balance in this account dropped below zero thirty-four times.
B. The Court Reporter Matter
Respondent ordered copies of a deposition transcript and failed to pay the court reporter who prepared the transcript.Â  When the court reporter attempted to collect on the bill from Respondent, Respondent asserted that it was his clientâ€™s obligation to pay the bill.Â  Eventually, the court reporter sought assistance from the presiding judge, who wrote Respondent two letters insisting that Respondent pay the bill.Â  Although Respondent ultimately settled his clientâ€™s case for an amount that would have covered the bill, the client reneged on the settlement and refused to sign the release.Â  Respondent never paid the bill, and the bill now totals $4,219.80.
C. The Jury Questionnaire Matter
In connection with the same lawsuit, Respondent ordered a copy of a jury questionnaire packet.Â  The invoice provided to Respondent requested payment of $344.06.Â  Respondent did not pay this bill and instead asked his client to do so.Â  The client did not pay the bill, however, and the bill allegedly remains unpaid.
D. The Client A Matter
Respondent received a call from a non-lawyer assistant who worked for an attorney who had been suspended from the practice of law.Â  The assistant asked whether Respondent would take over some of the suspended attorneyâ€™s cases.Â  After speaking with the suspended attorney, Respondent agreed to review some of the files.Â  One of these files pertained to an automobile collision claim for Client A.
According to ODC, Client A, a resident of New York, had a potential personal injury claim and Client Aâ€™s mother had consulted the suspended attorney about pursuing this claim.Â  Respondent reviewed this file, contacted Client Aâ€™s mother, and agreed with the mother that Respondent would send letters of protection to Client Aâ€™s medical providers.Â  In these letters, Respondent indicated that Client A had retained Respondentâ€™s firm to represent him in connection with the accident.Â  According to ODC, these representations were false because Respondent had no intention of representing Client A unless the at-fault party was willing to pay a settlement in the matter.
Respondent also allegedly agreed with Client Aâ€™s mother that he would send a â€œscare letterâ€ to the at-fault party.Â  In the letter, Respondent falsely indicated that he had been retained by Client A and Respondent accused the at-fault party of perjuring himself in traffic court.Â  Respondent demanded payment of Client Aâ€™s claim and Respondent asserted that if the party did not settle the case within two weeks, Respondent would contact the local judge and prosecutor for the purpose of pursuing perjury charges.Â  Respondent received no response and took no further action.
E. The Property Dispute Matter
A party involved in a dispute over the purchase of real property retained Respondent to represent him in the dispute.Â  On his clientâ€™s behalf, Respondent sent a letter to the adverse party in the dispute informing the party of Respondentâ€™s representation.Â  The letter additionally accused the adverse party of extortion and grand larceny.Â  Furthermore, the letter indicated that Respondent had contacted the solicitorâ€™s office, who had in turn been in contact with the sheriff and the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division about the matter.Â  The letter stated that Respondent intended to file a civil action based on the dispute and the letter indicated that the solicitor was going to handle the criminal case.Â  Respondent further asserted in the letter that he believed the adverse party â€œwould likely serve prison timeâ€ as a result of his conduct.
According to ODC, Respondentâ€™s representations that he had been in contact with the solicitorâ€™s office and with law enforcement were false.Â  In response to this letter, the adverse party offered to refund Respondentâ€™s clientâ€™s money in exchange for a release.Â  Seeking additional information, Respondent replied to this offer and requested a response from the adverse party within three days.Â  Respondent asserted that after that time he would â€œnot be able to stop the process of this action and [the adverse party] will be picked up.â€
F. The Process Server Matter
The complainants in this matter are process servers who were retained to serve a summons, complaint, and interrogatories on Respondentâ€™s client.Â  The complainants attempted to serve Respondentâ€™s client at her workplace, but the woman who answered the door at the building alleged that Respondentâ€™s client was not present at that time.Â  The complainants waited outside the business, observed Respondentâ€™s client leave the building, and attempted to serve Respondentâ€™s client in the parking lot when she returned.Â  The complainants photographed their attempt to serve Respondentâ€™s client, but the client denied that she was the person named in the pleadings.Â  The client threw the pleadings back at the complainants and then closed the gate to the parking lot, locking the complainants inside the lot.
The client then instructed an employee to call Respondent.Â  When Respondent arrived, he used his car to further block the complainantsâ€™ exit and he asserted that the complainantsâ€™ photographing his client violated his clientâ€™s rights.Â  The complainants asked that they be allowed to leave, but Respondent refused to move his vehicle.Â  The complainants eventually phoned the police, and after the police arrived, Respondent moved his vehicle so the complainants could leave.
G. The Custody Dispute Matter
Respondent represented a defendant in a custody dispute in family court.Â  In connection with the case, Respondent issued three subpoenas listing Respondent as the attorney for the plaintiff, even though Respondent represented the defendant.Â  One subpoena was served on the Department of Social Services requesting responses to discovery, and a second subpoena was served on the plaintiffâ€™s landlord demanding information regarding the plaintiffâ€™s rental agreement.Â  The third subpoena was directed to the defendantâ€™s childâ€™s doctor and requested discovery responses.Â  According to ODC, these subpoenas violated several court rules.Â  The record discloses that the family court held a sanction hearing relating to this conduct and that the judge admonished Respondent for his conduct.
H. The Client B Matter
Respondent received approximately $18,000.00 in settlement of a claim brought by his client, Client B.Â  Respondent issued a check from his office account to Client B for $11,000.00 as her portion of the settlement.Â  The check was returned to Client Bâ€™s bank due to Respondentâ€™s account lacking funds sufficient to cover the check.Â  Client B made several attempts to obtain her money from Respondent, and although Respondent eventually issued a second check to Client B, this check contained no date and the letter accompanying the check requested that it not be negotiated until Respondent confirmed that there were funds sufficient to cover it.Â  According to ODC, Client B has still not received her portion of the settlement proceeds from her claim.
I. The Client C Matter
Respondent collected $17,000.00 for Client C and failed to pay her medical bills.Â  According to ODC, Respondent has not responded to the notice of an investigation in this matter.
Panelâ€™s Recommendation
The Panel noted that because Respondent did not appear at the disciplinary hearing, Respondent was deemed to have admitted the factual allegations of the formal charges and conceded to ODCâ€™s recommended sanction.Â  See Rule 24(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  Based upon these facts and ODCâ€™s recommendations, the Panel found that Respondent violated the following Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.15 (failing to safekeep client funds); Rule 1.3 (diligence); Rule 3.4 (fairness to opposing party and counsel); Rule 4.1 (truthfulness in statements to others); Rule 4.3 (dealing with an unrepresented person); Rule 4.4 (respect for rights of third persons); Rule 4.5 (threatening criminal prosecution); Rule 5.3 (failing to adequately supervise nonlawyer employee); Rule 5.5 (assisting in the unauthorized practice of law); Rule 8.1 (cooperation in disciplinary matters); Rule 8.4(b) (committing a criminal act); Rule 8.4(d) (dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (conduct prejudicial to the administration of justice).
ODC recommended that Respondent be disbarred from the practice of law, and the Panel held that even without Respondentâ€™s concession of the appropriateness of this sanction, disbarment was the proper punishment in this matter.Â  The Panel based this finding on two aggravating factors.Â  First, the Panel held that this matter presented multiple violations including repeated conduct calling Respondentâ€™s honesty and integrity into question.Â  Second, the Panel held that Respondentâ€™s failure to answer the charges or appear at the disciplinary hearing indicated an obvious disinterest in the practice of law.Â  For these reasons, the Panel recommended that Respondent be disbarred from the practice of law.
Discussion
The South Carolina Supreme Court possesses the ultimate responsibility of determining sanctions in attorney disciplinary matters.Â  In re Rushton, 286 S.C. 543, 544, 335 S.E.2d 238, 238 (1985).Â  The instant case presents several different acts of serious misconduct, and after fully considering the misconduct at issue, we hold that disbarment is the appropriate sanction in this matter.
As we have recounted, Respondent failed to properly disburse settlement money in both the Client B and Client C matters, threatened criminal prosecution in order to gain advantage in a civil matter, was untruthful in statements and conduct towards others, and systematically failed to properly oversee and fulfill the financial obligations of his law practice.Â  Such conduct reflects extremely poorly on the legal profession and has the potential to inflict direct harm on members of the general public.Â  In short, we agree with the Panel that the instant case presents repeated conduct calling Respondentâ€™s honesty and integrity into question.Â  
 
Furthermore, we agree with the Panelâ€™s finding that Respondentâ€™s conduct indicates an obvious disinterest in the practice of law.Â  By all accounts, Respondent has left this jurisdiction with no apparent intention of returning.Â  Respondent departed this jurisdiction with the knowledge that disciplinary action against him was imminent,[3] and since his departure, Respondent has shown no regard for the status of his license to practice law in South Carolina.Â  As this Court has noted, a central purpose of the attorney disciplinary process is to protect the public from unscrupulous or indifferent lawyers.Â  In re Hall, 333 S.C. 247, 251, 509 S.E.2d 266, 268 (1998).Â  Furthermore, we have disbarred attorneys who fail to answer formal charges or appear at hearings before the Panel or this Court in egregious cases.Â  See, e.g., In re Wofford, 330 S.C. 522, 500 S.E.2d 486 (1998). Â Respondent has violated numerous provisions of Rule 7 of the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, set forth in Rule 413, SCACR, by violating the Rules of Professional Conduct; by failing to respond to a lawful demand from a disciplinary authority; by being convicted of a serious crime; by engaging in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or bring the court or legal profession into disrepute, or demonstrating an unfitness to practice law; by violating the oath of office; and by willfully violating the financial record keeping requirements contained in Rule 417, SCACR.Â  In light of this misconduct, the Panelâ€™s recommended sanction of disbarment is more than adequately justified.
Conclusion
We conclude Respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants disbarment from the practice of law.Â  Within fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, Respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of this Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender his Certificate of Admission to the Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court. Â 
Within thirty (30) days of the date of this opinion, ODC and Respondent shall file a restitution plan with the Court.  In the plan, Respondent shall agree to pay restitution to any party who incurred losses as a result of his misconduct in connection with this matter.Â  Furthermore, in addition to all other requirements Respondent must meet to be reinstated under Rule 413, no petition for reinstatement shall be accepted until Respondent has filed proof that he has made full restitution to all institutions and individuals who have lost money as a result of his misconduct, including restitution to the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection for any payment it may make.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.


[1] The record illustrates that in 2005, the SLED agent attempting to serve Respondent had discussions with Respondentâ€™s neighbor and also the current owner of Respondentâ€™s former place of business.Â  Both individuals professed that they had not seen Respondent in over a year and that Respondent had previously indicated that he would shortly be moving to the country of Nigeria.Â  According to the United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement Division, the last entry on Respondentâ€™s passport is dated December 24, 2004 and indicates that Respondent left the United States for Amsterdam, Holland, via the Atlanta International Airport.Â  SLED has placed Respondentâ€™s information in the Treasury Enforcement System so that local law enforcement will be notified if Respondent re-enters the United States.
[2] Respondent was born in Lagos, Nigeria, and moved to the United States to attend Winona State University in Winona, Minnesota, in 1980.Â  Respondent received his undergraduate degree from that institution in 1990.Â  Respondent attended William Mitchell College of Law in St. Paul, Minnesota, and graduated in June 1993.
[3] This Court refused to accept an Agreement for Discipline by Consent between Respondent and ODC in December 2004.

title: In the Matter of Milton Demetrios Stratos
description: This is an opinion in which the Court publicly reprimands an attorney for misconduct.
text:
IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


	
		
			
				In the Matter of Milton Demetrios Stratos, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No.Â  26362
Submitted June 21, 2007 - Filed July 23, 2007Â  

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


	
		
			
				Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Ericka M. Williams, Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				Milton Demetrios Stratos, of Mount Pleasant,
				pro se.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and agrees to the imposition of either an admonition or public reprimand.Â  We accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Respondent was appointed to represent a client in connection with the appeal of his August 2, 2005 criminal convictions.[1]Â  On February 17, 2006, the South Carolina Court of Appeals wrote respondent and instructed him to contact the Office of Appellate Defense within ten (10) days to request a transcript in his clientâ€™s case and to also provide a copy of the correspondence to the Court.Â  The Court of Appeals notified respondent that an Initial Brief and Designation of Matter would be due to be served and filed within thirty (30) days of the date respondent received the transcript.Â  
 
On February 28, 2006, respondent wrote his client and urged him to consider using the Office of Appellate Defense to handle his appeal as respondent lacked the necessary experience and/or aptitude in perfecting appeals.Â  On March 3, 2006, the client responded by letter and informed respondent that the proper course of action would be for respondent to file a motion to withdraw from the case.Â  In that letter, the client also informed respondent that he would not consider using the Office of Appellate Defense to handle his appeal.Â 
 
On March 10, 2006, the Court of Appeals dismissed the clientâ€™s appeal due to respondentâ€™s failure to secure the required transcript and his failure to provide the necessary information to the Court.Â  On March 29, 2006, the Clerk of the Court of Appeals issued a remittitur to the Charleston County Clerk of Court after respondent failed to file a Petition for Reinstatement of the appeal.Â 
 
On April 19, 2006, the Supreme Court of South Carolina dismissed the clientâ€™s appeal and denied the clientâ€™s motion to reinstate the appeal.Â  However, the Court noted that the denial was without prejudice to the client to seek relief under White v. State, 263 S.C. 110, 208 S.E.2d 35 (1974).Â Â  Â 
When respondent received initial notice of his appointment to represent the client, he erroneously assumed he was appointed to represent the client at trial in General Sessions Court.Â  Respondent filed the customary discovery motions with the trial court (which respondent now acknowledges was of no relevance since his client had already been convicted).Â  Respondent wrote one letter dated February 28, 2006 to the Office of Appellate Defense wherein he requested a return telephone call regarding the clientâ€™s case.Â  Respondent represents that he made several telephone calls to the Office of Appellate Defense but never received a response to his communications.Â  Prior to May 11, 2006, respondent did not file any pleadings, make any appearances with the South Carolina Court of Appeals, or take any meaningful action on behalf of his clientâ€™s appeal.Â 
 
On November 19, 2006, after receiving notice of his clientâ€™s complaint from ODC, respondent met with his client for the first time.Â  As a result of his neglect of his clientâ€™s appeal and his failure to adequately and timely communicate with his client, respondentâ€™s client lost his right to have his appeal heard by the South Carolina Court of Appeals and/or the Supreme Court of South Carolina.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â 
 
LAW
Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct), Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession into disrepute), and Rule 7(a)(6) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate the oath of office).Â  Respondent admits that by his misconduct he has violated the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR, particularly Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation to a client), Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep client reasonably informed about status of a matter and promptly comply with reasonable requests for information); 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct); and Rule 8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct prejudicial to the administration of justice).Â  Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.Â Â Â Â Â Â   
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] The client was convicted of murder and possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â
