title: Skiba v. Gessner
description: This case involves the issue of whether the trial court properly found respondent was not required to have a license to perform the work requested by appellant.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Raymond Skiba, d/b/a Skiba Landscaping and Construction, Respondent,
				v.
				Marjorie Sue Gessner and Terral Monty Matlock, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26363
Heard June 7, 2007 - Filed July 23, 2007Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				James P. Stevens, Jr., of Stevens Law Firm, P.C., of Loris, for appellant.
				David J. Canty, of David J. Canty, P.A., of Myrtle Beach, for respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Respondent was hired by appellantâ€™s[1] then fiancÃ©e, Terral Matlock, to perform lot clearing and the removal of unmarked trees, roots, and ground debris in return for $13,200.Â  Appellant did not pay respondent for the work, but instead sent respondent a complaint letter, which stated the scope of respondentâ€™s work included root-raking and cleaning of the lot to prepare it for landscaping. [2]Â  Respondent perfected a mechanicâ€™s lien and later brought an action for foreclosure.Â  Appellant answered and filed a counterclaim that respondent left the job unfinished and that she had to hire someone else to complete the work.
At the conclusion of the trial, the trial court granted appellantâ€™s motion to dismiss on the ground that respondent violated S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-11-30 (2001),[3] by not having a contractorâ€™s license.Â  The court noted that the work for which respondent contracted fell within the definition of general construction because it was an improvement of any kind to real property.Â  Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-11-370 (Supp. 2006), which states that an entity which does not have a valid license as required by Chapter 40 may not bring an action at law or in equity to enforce the provisions of a contract, the court found that because respondent did not have a license, he could not bring an action against appellant.Â  The court dismissed appellantâ€™s counterclaim alleging that respondent left the job unfinished and caused damage to the property for lack of proof.
Respondent then filed a motion for reconsideration.Â  During the hearing on the motion, the trial court allowed appellant to amend her complaint to add the affirmative defense of illegality of the contract.Â  The court further concluded that the case should be re-opened so that the parties could take more depositions and could produce the rules and regulations of the Department of Labor, Licensing, and Regulation as they relate to Â§ 40-11-30.
At the next hearing, the deposition of Ron Galloway, the administrator of the South Carolina Contractorâ€™s Licensing Board was submitted.Â  Galloway stated he had reviewed the documents between the parties and concluded no building was involved in the contract and that respondentâ€™s work was not in preparation for a building site.Â  He stated it was simply â€œmoving dirt.â€Â  Galloway stated that clearing, grubbing, and removing debris does not require a contractorâ€™s license and that respondentâ€™s work was exempt from the licensing requirement.
The court concluded respondent was not required to have a license to perform the work requested by appellant, and therefore, that the contract was not illegal as it had earlier ruled. Â In its order, the trial court found that respondent was entitled to $14,700; however, the court subtracted $6,300 for respondentâ€™s improper removal of trees.Â  Accordingly, the court found respondent was entitled to $8,400 plus prejudgment interest.
ISSUE
Did the trial court properly find in respondentâ€™s favor?
DISCUSSION
At the time respondent perfected his mechanicâ€™s lien and brought the foreclosure action, it was understood by the parties that respondentâ€™s work had been completed in preparation for appellantâ€™s subsequent building of a home on the property.Â  During the trial, appellant determined that the contract was illegal because respondent did not have a contractorâ€™s license at the time the work was performed.Â  At this point, the trial court originally correctly dismissed respondentâ€™s action on the ground the contract was illegal.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-11-30 (2001) (no individual may practice as a contractor by performing or offering to perform contracting work for which the total cost of construction is greater than five thousand dollars for general contracting); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 40-11-20(8) (2001) (â€œâ€˜General constructionâ€™ means the installation, replacement, or repair of a building, structure, . . .or improvement of any kind to real property.â€).
It is apparent that when respondent discovered that he was required to have a license to legally perform the work for appellant, he decided to take an inconsistent position.Â  It is at this point when respondent claimed that his work was actually not in preparation for a building, but was in preparation for landscaping.Â  After hearing Gallowayâ€™s deposition, the trial court concluded respondent was not required to have a license to perform the work.
Because the work performed by respondent, as respondent now claims, was for the purpose of preparing the lot for landscaping and not for any work related to a building or structure, appellant contends a mechanicâ€™s lien cannot attach to the property.Â  Appellantâ€™s argument is based on S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(a) (2007), which states that for a person to have a mechanicâ€™s lien, the person must perform or furnish labor or furnish materials that are â€œactually used in the erection, alteration, or repair of a building or structure upon real estate.â€Â  Section 29-5-10(a) provides that the â€œlabor performed or furnished in the erection, alteration, or repair of any building or structure upon any real estate includes the . . . work of making the real estate suitable as a site for the building or structure.â€
A mechanicâ€™s lien exists only by virtue of statute; therefore, oneâ€™s right to a mechanicâ€™s lien is wholly dependent upon the language of the statute creating it.Â  Clo-Car Trucking Co., Inc. v. Clifflure Estates of South Carolina, Inc., 282 S.C. 573, 320 S.E.2d 51 (Ct. App. 1984)Â  We are not at liberty to depart from the plain meaning of the mechanic lienâ€™s statutory language.Â  Id.
In Clo-Car, the Court of Appeals found that land cleared and graded for the purpose of a road is not a building or a structure within the meaning of the statute.Â  The Court of Appeals concluded that under Â§ 29-5-10,a mechanicâ€™s lien cannot attach to land or to an ownerâ€™s interest in land where the work done is unconnected with and forms no integral part of the erection, alteration, or repair of either a building or a structure of some description.Â  See also George A.Z. Johnson, Jr., Inc. v. Barnhill, 279 S.C. 242, 306 S.E.2d 216 (1983) (to establish a mechanicâ€™s lien, it is generally necessary that the labor performed go into something which has attached to and become a part of the real estate, adding to the value thereof).
On the current facts of this case, respondentâ€™s work was completed for the purpose of preparing the land for landscaping and not in connection with the erection, alteration, or repair of a building or structure. Â Accordingly, a mechanicâ€™s lien could not attach and the trial court erred by finding in favor of respondent.Â  Therefore, the decision of the trial court is
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Appellants were not yet married at the time the work was completed.Â  Appellant Matlockâ€™s motion for summary judgment was granted on the basis he had no property interest in the lot.Â  Accordingly, for purposes of this appeal, we will only be referring to Appellant Gessner.
[2] Appellant asserts, however, that her position has always been that the site work was for the purpose of improving the real estate for the erection of a residence. 
 
[3] Section 40-11-30 provides that â€œ[n]o entity or individual may practice as a contractor by performing . . . contracting work for which the total cost of construction is greater than five thousand dollars for general contracting . . ..â€

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Chem-Nuclear Systems, LLC, Plaintiff,
				v.
				South Carolina Board of Health and Environmental Control, Defendant, 
				
				and Sierra Club, Intervenor.
			
		
	


ORIGINAL JURISDICTION

Opinion No. 26364Â Â Â  

Heard June 20, 2007 - Filed July 23, 2007
RELIEF GRANTED


	
		
			
				M. Elizabeth Crum, and Sara S. Rogers, both of McNair Law Firm, of Columbia; and Mary D. Shahid, of McNair Law Firm, of Charleston, for Plaintiff.
				Carlisle Roberts, Jr., of Columbia, for Defendant.
				James S. Chandler, Jr., and Amy E. Armstrong, both of South Carolina Environmental Law Project, of Pawleys Island; and Robert Guild, of Columbia, for Intervenor.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Special Counsel Robert D. Cook, and
				Assistant Attorney General Thomas Parkin C. Hunter, all of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae.
			
		
	


 
JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  We accepted this case in our original jurisdiction to determine the application and effect of Act No. 387, 2006 S.C. Acts 387, (â€œAct 387â€) to an appeal pending before the South Carolina Board of Health and Environmental Control (Board) on the effective date of Act 387.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Chem-Nuclear Systems, LLC, (â€œChem-Nuclearâ€) operates a low-level radioactive waste disposal facility in Barnwell County.Â  Chem-Nuclearâ€™s facility is licensed by the State of South Carolina through the Department of Health and Environmental Control (DHEC).Â  On March 15, 2004, DHECâ€™s Office of Environmental Quality Control renewed Chem-Nuclearâ€™s license for the facility.Â 
 
Sierra Club subsequently filed a contested case with the Administrative Law Court (ALC), challenging the renewal of Chem-Nuclearâ€™s license.Â  The ALC upheld the license renewal.Â  Sierra Club v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Envtl. Control and Chem-Nuclear Sys., LLC, Docket No. 04-ALJ-07-0126-CC (S.C. Admin. Law Ct. Oct. 13, 2005).Â  Sierra Club then appealed the ALCâ€™s decision to the Board pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610 (2005) amended by Act 387 Â§ 5 (codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610 (Supp. 2006)).Â  Prior to the effective date of Act 387, the Board notified Sierra Club, Chem-Nuclear, and DHECâ€”the parties to the appealâ€”that the Board would lose its jurisdiction to hear the appeal when Act 387 became effective.Â  The appeal remained pending before the Board on the effective date of Act 387, and the Board, at the request of the Attorney General, subsequently reversed its position and informed the parties that it did have jurisdiction to hear Sierra Clubâ€™s pending appeal.Â 
 
In response, Chem-Nuclear filed this action requesting a declaration that Act 387 deprives the Board of jurisdiction to review the pending appeal in Sierra Club. 
 
ISSUE

	Did Act 387 deprive the Board of jurisdiction to hear an appeal from the ALCâ€™s decision in
	Sierra Club v. South Carolina Department of Â Â Â  Health and Environmental Control and Chem-Nuclear Systems, LLC,  Docket No. 04-ALJ-07-0126-CC (S.C. Admin. Law Ct. Oct. 13, 2005), Â Â Â Â  which was pending before the Board on the date Act 387 became effective?

LAW/ANALYSIS
Act 387, which was signed into law on June 9, 2006, and became effective on July 1, 2006, substantially reformed the South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act in order â€œto provide a uniform procedure for contested cases and appeals from administrative agencies.â€Â  Act 387 Â§ 53.Â  Sections 55 and 57 of Act 387 are crucial to the outcome of this declaratory judgment action.Â  These sections provide:

	Savings clause
	SECTION 55. The repeal or amendment by this act of any law, whether temporary or permanent or civil or criminal, does not affect pending Â Â  actions, rights, duties, or liabilities founded thereon, or alter, discharge, release or extinguish any penalty, forfeiture, or liability incurred under Â  the repealed or amended law, unless the repealed or amended provision shall so expressly provide.Â  After the effective date of this act, all laws repealed or amended by this act must be taken and treated as remaining in full force and effect for the purpose of sustaining any pending or vested right, civil action, special proceeding, criminal prosecution, or appeal existing as of the effective date of this act, and for the enforcement of rights, duties, penalties, forfeitures, and liabilities as they stood under the repealed or amended laws.
	Time effective
	SECTION 57. This act takes effect on July 1, 2006, and applies to any actions pending on or after the effective date of the act.Â  No pending or vested right, civil action, special proceeding, or appeal of a final administrative decision exists under the former law as of the effective date of this act, except for appeals of Department of Health and Environmental Control Ocean and Coastal Resource Management and Environmental Quality Control permits that are before the Administrative Law Court on the effective date of this act and petitions for judicial review that are pending before the circuit court.Â  For those actions only, the department shall hear appeals from the administrative law judges and the circuit court shall hear pending petitions for judicial review in accordance with the former law.Â  Thereafter, any appeal of 
	those actions shall proceed as provided in this act for review.  For 
	all other actions pending on the effective date of this act, the action proceeds as provided in this act for review.

The cardinal rule of statutory interpretation is to ascertain and effectuate the intention of the legislature.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000).Â  In ascertaining the intent of the legislature, a court should not focus on any single section or provision but should consider the language of the statute as a whole.Â  Mid-State Auto Auction of Lexington, Inc. v. Altman, 324 S.C. 65, 69, 476 S.E.2d 690, 692 (1996).Â  The language of a statute must be read in a sense which harmonizes with its subject matter and accords with its general purpose.Â  Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992).Â  
 
The right of appeal arises from and is controlled by statutory law.Â  Hagood v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 194, 607 S.E.2d 707, 708 (2005).Â  Generally, the repeal of a statute without a savings clause operates retroactively to expunge pending claims, but a proper savings clause will have the effect of preserving a pending suit.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Natural Res. v. McDonald, 367 S.C. 531, 535, 626 S.E.2d 816, 818 (Ct. App. 2006); Deltoro v. McMullen, 322 S.C. 328, 333, 471 S.E.2d 742, 745 (Ct. App. 1996), superseded by statute on other grounds as stated in Badeaux v. Davis, 337 S.C. 195, 522 S.E.2d 835 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Accordingly, Sierra Clubâ€™s pending appeal was preserved by Section 55, a savings clause, in Act 387.
Prior to the enactment of Act 387, the Board had jurisdiction to review final decisions of the ALC, i.e., Sierra Clubâ€™s appeal.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610 (2005) amended by Act 387 Â§ 5 (codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610 (Supp. 2006)).Â  Yet, under Act 387, the Court of Appeals has jurisdiction over appeals from final decisions of the ALC.Â  See Act 387 Â§Â§ 5, 15.[1]Â  In this action, we must determine whether Act 387 changed the forum for Sierra Clubâ€™s pending appeal from the Board to the Court of Appeals.Â  
 
Section 57 requires Act 387 to apply â€œto any actions pending on or after the effective date.â€Â  Clearly, Sierra Clubâ€™s appeal was pending on the effective date of Act 387.Â  However, Section 57 creates an exception to this general rule of applicability and mandates the former law continue to apply to â€œappeals of Department of Health and Environmental Control . . . [Office of] Environmental Quality Control permits that are before the Administrative Law Court on the effective date of this act and petitions for judicial review that are pending before the circuit court.â€Â  The license at issue in this case was renewed by DHECâ€™s Office of Environmental Quality Control, but the ALC was divested of jurisdiction and the Board obtained jurisdiction over the case when Sierra Club filed a petition for review of the ALCâ€™s decision with the Board.Â  See generally Jackson v. Speed, 326 S.C. 289, 311, 486 S.E.2d 750, 761 (1997) (service of notice of intent to appeal divests the lower court of jurisdiction over the order appealed).Â  Therefore, Sierra Clubâ€™s appeal was before the Board, not the ALC or the circuit court, on the effective date of Act 387, and consequently, the exception in Section 57 to apply the former law to certain cases that were pending before the ALC or circuit court on July 1, 2006, is not applicable to Sierra Clubâ€™s appeal.Â  See Carolina Power & Light Co. v. City of Bennettsville, 314 S.C. 137, 139, 442 S.E.2d 177, 179 (1994) (â€œWhen statutory terms are clear and unambiguous, there is no room for construction and courts are required to apply them according to their literal meaning.â€).Â  Pursuant to the plain language of Section 57, the Board does not currently have jurisdiction over the appeal in Sierra Club.
Sierra Club opposes this construction of Sections 55 and 57.Â  Sierra Club contends this construction leaves it without an avenue for an appeal because it can no longer timely perfect an appeal in the Court of Appeals.Â  See Rule 203, SCACR (requiring notice of appeal to be filed within 30 days after receipt of the decision); Act 387 Â§ 5 (codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610 (Supp. 2006)) (same).Â  This argument is without merit.Â  Section 55, the savings clause, acts not only to preserve Sierra Clubâ€™s right to appeal the ALCâ€™s final decision but also to preserve Sierra Clubâ€™s perfected appeal of the decision.Â  See Deltoro, 322 S.C. at 333, 471 S.E.2d at 745 (â€œ[A] proper savings clause will have the effect of preserving a pending suit.â€).Â  Because Section 55 preserves Sierra Clubâ€™s pending appeal, Sierra Club is not required to re-perfect its appeal in the Court of Appeals; instead, Section 57 effectively transfers jurisdiction to the Court of Appeals of Sierra Clubâ€™s appeal.Â  See Act 387 Â§ 57 (â€œFor all other actions pending on the effective date of this act, the action proceeds as provided in this act for review.â€); Cf. Rule 204(a), SCACR (â€œIn the event that the notice of appeal is filed in the wrong appellate court, the appellate court in . . . which the matter is filed shall issue an order transferring the case to the appropriate appellate court.â€).Â  
 
CONCLUSION
We declare the Board does not have jurisdiction under Act 387 to hear the pending appeal in Sierra Club, but the Court of Appeals has jurisdiction over the appeal.Â  Accordingly, we order the appeal in Sierra Club be transferred to the Court of Appeals pursuant to Section 57 of Act 387.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Â Section 5 of Act 387 (codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610 (Supp. 2006)) states, in relevant part:

	(A) For quasi-judicial review of any final decision of an administrative law judge of cases involving departments governed by a board or commission authorized to exercise the sovereignty of the State, except the Department of Natural Resources and the Department of Health and Environmental Control, a petition by an aggrieved party must be filed with the appropriate board or commission and served on the opposing party not more than thirty days after the party receives the final decision and order of the administrative law judge.Â  Appeal in these matters is by right.Â  A party aggrieved by a final decision of a board in such a case is entitled to judicial review of that decision by the court of appeals under the provisions of (A) of this section.
	(B) For judicial review of 
	a final decision of an administrative law judge of cases in which review is 
	not governed by subsection (A),  including cases involving the Department of Natural Resources and the Department of Health and Environmental Control, a notice of appeal by an aggrieved party must be served and filed with the court of appeals as provided in the South Carolina Appellate Court Rules in civil cases and served on the opposing party not more than thirty days after the party receives the final decision and order of the administrative law judge. Appeal in these matters is by right.

Section 15 of Act 387 (codified at S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-8-200 (Supp. 2006)) provides the Court of Appeals with â€œjurisdiction over any case in which an appeal is taken from an order, judgment, or decree of the circuit court, family court, a final decision of an agency, or a final decision of an administrative law judge. Â This jurisdiction is appellate only. . . .â€

title: Furtick v. SC Department of Corrections
description: This is a prison grievance matter where the Court reverses the circuit court's finding that the ALJ lacked subject matter jurisdiction.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				James Furtick, Appellant
				v.
				South Carolina Department of Corrections, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26270
Submitted January 18, 2007 - Refiled July 30, 2007Â Â  

REVERSED


	
		
			
				James Furtick, pro se, of Bennettsville, for Appellant.
				Barton J. Vincent, Deputy General Counsel, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  This is a direct appeal from the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the Administrative Law Courtâ€™s (ALC) summary dismissal of appellant James Furtickâ€™s prison grievance matter.Â  After we issued our original opinion in which we reversed, Furtick v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corrections, Op. No. 26270 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed February 20, 2007) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 6 at 89), respondent filed a petition for rehearing.Â  We now withdraw our original opinion and issue this opinion. Â We deny respondentâ€™s petition for rehearing and reverse the circuit courtâ€™s decision.
FACTS
In 2001, when Furtick was an inmate at Lee Correctional Institution, the Department of Corrections (DOC) charged him with possession of contraband.[1]Â  After a major disciplinary hearing was held, Furtick was found guilty of the offense and reprimanded.Â  As a result of the reprimand, Furtick alleges he did not earn his good time credit for the month of the infraction.Â  Furtick appealed from this disciplinary decision through the DOCâ€™s internal grievance system; the DOC denied his grievance.
Furtick appealed the denial of his grievance to the ALC, and the DOC moved to dismiss the action based on a lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Finding that Furtick had no liberty interest in good time credits which he was unable to earn as a result of a rule violation, the ALC dismissed the matter.
Furtick sought review from the circuit court.Â  The circuit court also found no liberty interest was implicated and therefore affirmed the ALCâ€™s decision.Â 
 
ISSUE

	Did the circuit court err in finding the ALC lacked jurisdiction over Furtickâ€™s claim?

DISCUSSION
Furtick argues that the circuit court erred by finding that the ALC lacked subject matter jurisdiction to review his grievance.Â  We agree.
Through statute, the State provides that an inmate is â€œentitled to a deduction from the term of his sentenceâ€ if he â€œfaithfully observe[s] all the rules of the institution â€¦ and has not been subjected to punishment for misbehavior.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-13-210(A) (2007).Â  However, â€œ[i]f a prisoner â€¦ violates one of the rules of the institution during his term of imprisonment, all or part of the good conduct credit he has earned may be forfeited in the discretion of the Director of the Department of Corrections.â€Â  Id. Â§ 24-13-210(D).
In Wolff v. McDonnell, 418 U.S. 539 (1974), the United States Supreme Court explained that inmates have certain due process rights when good time credits are at issue:

	It is true that the Constitution itself does not guarantee good-time credit for satisfactory behavior while in prisonâ€¦. Â [The State] may have the authority to create, or not, a right to a shortened prison sentence through the accumulation of credits for good behavior, and it is true that the Due Process Clause does not require a hearing â€˜in every conceivable case of government impairment of private interest.â€™â€¦ Â But the State having created the right to good time and itself recognizing that its deprivation is a sanction authorized for major misconduct, the prisonerâ€™s interest has real substance and is sufficiently embraced within Fourteenth Amendment â€˜libertyâ€™ to entitle him to those minimum procedures appropriate under the circumstances and required by the Due Process Clause to insure that the state-created right is not arbitrarily abrogated.

Id. at 557 (citation omitted); see also Sandin v. Conner, 515 U.S. 472, 483-84 (1995) (the States may, under certain circumstances, create liberty interests which are protected by the Due Process Clause); Henderson v. Commâ€™rs of Barnstable County, 730 N.E.2d 362, 370 (Mass. App. Ct. 2000) (â€œThe entitlement to statutory good time credit is a liberty interest.â€).
The USSC noted in Wolff that punishment in the form of â€œthe forfeiture or withholding of good-time creditsâ€ affects the term of confinement.Â  Wolff, 418 U.S. at 547 (emphasis added).Â  Additionally, in Superintendent, Mass. Corr. Inst. v. Hill, 472 U.S. 445, 454 (1985), the USSC specifically stated the following:Â  â€œWhere a prisoner has a liberty interest in good time credits, the loss of such credits threatens his prospective freedom from confinement by extending the length of imprisonment. Â Thus the inmate has a strong interest in assuring that the loss of good time credits is not imposed arbitrarily.â€
In Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 527 S.E.2d 742 (2000), we acknowledged that â€œ[t]he statutory right to sentence-related credits is a protected â€˜libertyâ€™ interest under the Fourteenth Amendment, entitling an inmate to minimal due process to ensure the state-created right was not arbitrarily abrogated.â€Â  Id. at 370, 527 S.E.2d at 750 (citing Wolff, supra).Â  We held in Al-Shabazz that the DOCâ€™s disciplinary and grievance procedures are consistent with the due process standards outlined by the USSC in Wolff.Â  See id. at 372-73, 527 S.E.2d at 751-52 (for extensive discussion on the DOCâ€™s procedures for major disciplinary hearings). Â Moreover, we also held that an inmate generally could not raise a non-collateral claim, such as one involving the forfeiture of good-time credits, via the Post-Conviction Relief Act.Â  Id. at 367-68, 527 S.E.2d at 749.
We held, however, that an inmate could pursue review of certain grievance decisions made by the DOC by filing an action in the ALC pursuant to the Administrative Procedures Act (APA).Â  The Al-Shabazz Court stated that when an inmate challenges a disciplinary outcome, calculation of sentence‑related credits, custody status, or other condition of imprisonment, he could bring â€œa contested caseâ€ under the APA. Â Id. at 375, 527 S.E.2d at 753.Â  Thus, the ALC â€œsits in an appellate capacity to reviewâ€ these types of decisions.Â  Id. at 377, 527 S.E.2d at 754.Â  
 
Furthermore, â€œ[a]n inmate is entitled to judicial review of the final decision in a non-collateral or administrative matter, which includes a disciplinary hearing.â€Â  Id. at 377-78, 527 S.E.2d at 754.Â  We explained that judicial review must be available to determine â€œwhether prison officials have acted arbitrarily capriciously, or from personal bias.â€Â  Id. at 381, 527 S.E.2d at 756-57. 
We emphasized in Al-Shabazz that any judicial review would be of a â€œlimited natureâ€ and that the courts of this State would adhere to a â€œhands offâ€ doctrine when reviewing the decision from a major disciplinary hearing in which an inmate has a protected liberty interest due to the potential loss of sentence-related credits.Â  Id. at 382, 527 S.E.2d at 757.Â  Finally, the Al‑Shabazz Court recognized that most of these matters would be resolved without either ALC or judicial review, but nonetheless held that such review â€œmust be available.â€Â  Id. at 383, 527 S.E.2d at 757.[2] 
Several subsequent decisions have reiterated Al‑Shabazzâ€™s holding that the ALC has subject matter jurisdiction over an inmateâ€™s appeal when the claim sufficiently â€œimplicates a state-created liberty interest.â€Â  Sullivan v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corrections, 355 S.C. 437, 443, 586 S.E.2d 124, 127 (2003), cert. denied, 540 U.S. 1153 (2004); see also Furtick v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Prob., Parole & Pardon Servs., 352 S.C. 594, 598, 576 S.E.2d 146, 149, cert. denied, 539 U.S. 932 (2003) (in deciding whether Respondent was entitled to review of the Departmentâ€™s parole eligibility decision, the Court evaluated whether Respondent had a liberty interest in gaining access to the parole board); Steele v. Benjamin, 362 S.C. 66, 606 S.E.2d 499 (Ct. App. 2004) (the ALCâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction depends on whether there is a sufficient, state‑created liberty interest implicated).Â 
 
Furthermore, in Slezak v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corrections, 361 S.C. 327, 605 S.E.2d 506 (2004), cert. denied, 544 U.S. 1033 (2005), we clarified that the ALC has jurisdiction over all inmate grievance appeals that have been properly filed; the ALC, however, is not required to hold a hearing in every matter.Â  We stated in Slezak that summary dismissal would only be appropriate â€œwhere the inmateâ€™s grievance does not implicate a state-created liberty or property interest.â€Â  Id. at 331, 605 S.E.2d at 508. Â Thus, where a matter clearly implicates a loss of statutory sentence-related credits, the ALC may not summarily dismiss the action.[3]
Turning now to the instant case, we reiterate that the State of South Carolina clearly has created a liberty interest in good-time credits by enacting section 24-13-210.Â  Without a doubt, these credits for good behavior may be withheld or revoked as punishment when an inmate commits an offense while incarcerated or otherwise violates the rules of the institution.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-13-210(D).Â  Nonetheless, such a loss of good-time credits is reviewable by the ALC pursuant to Al-Shabazz and its progeny.Â  The matter is reviewable because the loss of good-time credits sufficiently â€œimplicates a state-created liberty interest.â€Â  Sullivan, 355 S.C. at 443, 586 S.E.2d at 127.Â  When a state-created liberty interest is implicated, the inmate is entitled to certain due process rights.Â  Wolff, supra.Â  While the DOCâ€™s disciplinary policies comport with those due process requirements, the purpose of allowing review is to ensure that due process was, in fact, accorded to the inmate and the inmateâ€™s right to the statutory credit was not â€œarbitrarily abrogated.â€Â  Wolff, 418 U.S. at 557; accord Al-Shabazz, supra.
We emphasize, however, that inmate litigation itself must comport with certain standards.Â  If a court finds a prisoner has: (1) submitted a malicious or frivolous claim, or one that is intended solely to harass the party filed against; (2) testified falsely or otherwise presented false evidence or information to the court; (3) unreasonably expanded or delayed a proceeding; or (4) abused the discovery process; then the â€œprisoner shall forfeit all or part of his earned work, education, or good conduct credits in an amount to be determinedâ€ by the DOC.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-27-200 (2007); see also Al-Shabazz, 338 S.C. at 381, 527 S.E.2d at 756.
In this case, Furtick sought review from the ALC and such review was denied by both the ALC and circuit court.Â  Accordingly, we reverse and remand to the ALC to hold a hearing on the denial of Furtickâ€™s grievance claim.
REVERSED.
MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â  TOAL, C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion.
CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my view, the majorityâ€™s holding today ignores the legislative intent expressed by the clear and unambiguous language of S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 24-13-210 and -230.Â  Further, I believe the majority discards our Courtâ€™s long-standing â€œhands-offâ€ approach to judicial supervision of internal prison disciplinary matters which do not amount to a violation of constitutional dimensions.Â  In adopting its position, the majority has interjected our courts into every prison disciplinary matter which may result in an inmateâ€™s lost opportunity to earn sentence-related credits including a multitude of minor disciplinary infractions which, but for todayâ€™s decision, would not otherwise trigger due process protections.Â  Therefore, I would affirm the circuit courtâ€™s decision finding that an inmate has no constitutionally significant interest in the loss of the opportunity to earn certain sentence-related credits.Â  However, I would modify the circuit courtâ€™s decision to reflect that the ALC has subject matter jurisdiction to review such inmate grievance matters and that the ALC may summarily decide these appeals without a hearing.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â 
 
Under our statutory law, Furtick does not have any protected liberty interest in the loss of the opportunity to earn sentence-related credits.Â  The United States Constitution does not provide an inmate with a guarantee of sentence-related credit for good behavior while incarcerated.Â  Wolff v. McDonnell, 418 U.S. 539, 557 (1974).Â  However, in some instances, a state may create a liberty interest which is protected by the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.Â  Sandin v. Conner, 515 U.S. 472, 484 (1995). Â Â A state creates a liberty interest in sentence-related credits only where an inmate has a legitimate expectation of receiving such credits.Â  See Bd. of Pardons v. Allen, 482 U.S. 369, 373 (1987) (citing Greenholtz v. Inmates of Nebraska Penal and Correctional Complex, 442 U.S. 1, 11 (1979)).Â  However, a liberty interest in sentence-related credits cannot be predicated on the unilateral expectation or hope to be released before the expiration of oneâ€™s term.Â  See Montgomery v. Anderson, 262 F.3d 641, 645 (7th Cir. 2001).Â  An inmate may obtain relief for the deprivation of sentence-related credits if he can demonstrate that â€œthe Stateâ€™s action. . . Â inevitably affect[ed] the duration of his sentence.â€ Â Â Sandin, 515 U.S. at 487. Â Generally, an inmate is not entitled to due process protection for State action that may only speculatively affect the duration of his sentence.Â  Id.Â Â Â  
 

	S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-13-210(A) provides:
	A prisoner convicted of an offense against this State, except a â€œno parole offenseâ€ as defined in Section 24-13-100, and sentenced to the custody of the Department of Corrections including a prisoner serving time in a local facility pursuant to a designated facility agreement authorized by Section 24-3-30, whose record of conduct shows that he has faithfully observed all the rules of the institution where he is confined and has not been subjected to punishment for misbehavior, is entitled to a deduction from the term of his sentence beginning with the day on which the service of his sentence commences to run, computed at the rate of twenty days for each month served. Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
	

In Busby v. Moore, this Court found that the legislature intended Â§ 24-13-210(A) to reward inmates with good-time credits only after they exhibit good behavior.Â  330 S.C. 201, 204, 498 S.E.2d 883, 884 (1998), overruled in part on other grounds by Al-Shabazz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 369, 527 S.E.2d 742, 750 (1999).Â Â  Additionally, this Court found that a prisonerâ€™s entitlement to good-time credits pursuant to Â§ 24-13-210(A) did not vest until the prisoner had served the appropriate amount of time and actually earned the credits.Â  Id. at 204, 498 S.E.2d at 885.Â Â Â  
 
In this case, Furtick was reprimanded for the violation of prison rules.Â  A collateral result of this reprimand was that Furtick was ineligible to earn his good-time credits during the month in which he was reprimanded.Â  Because Furtick did not lose any earned good-time credits as a result of the reprimand, in my view, we cannot say that the reprimand inevitably effected the duration of his sentence.Â 
 
A myriad of considerations affect whether an inmate is released before the conclusion of the original sentence.Â  In my view, Furtickâ€™s situation is markedly different from the situation where an inmate has already earned good-time credit and, by virtue of some punishment, is required to forfeit that credit.Â  In that case, the inmate no longer possesses merely a unilateral hope of a sentence reduction, but actually possesses a vested right to the good-time credit and reduction in sentence.Â  As we stated in Al-Shabazz, the withholding or forfeiture of earned good-time credit directly implicates a protected liberty interest.Â  338 S.C. at 370, 527 S.E.2d at 750. Â In contrast, the loss of the opportunity to earn good-time credit as a result of a prison rule violation does not implicate the same interest. 
 
Because the statute grants inmates good-time credit only after inmates demonstrate good behavior, no inmate is guaranteed or has a vested right in the maximum accrual of good-time credit.Â  Accordingly, I would find that an inmate does not have a legitimate expectation that he will receive good-time credits, but merely possesses only the hope that his behavior and observation of prison rules will be sufficient to entitle him to a reduction in his sentence.Â  Based on the language in Â§ 24-13-210(A) and our previous interpretation of the statute, I would hold that an inmate does not have a protected liberty interest in unearned good-time credits.Â  To hold otherwise would clearly frustrate the purpose and intent of the legislature in enacting the statute.Â 
 
An analysis of Â§ 24-13-230(A) reveals a similar conclusion.Â Â  The statute provides:

	The Director of the Department of Corrections may allow any prisoner in the custody of the department, except a prisoner convicted of a â€œno parole offenseâ€ as defined in Section 24-13-100, who is assigned to a productive duty assignment or who is regularly enrolled and actively participating in an academic, technical, or vocational training program, a reduction from the term of his sentence of zero to one day for every two days he is employed or enrolled. A maximum annual credit for both work credit and education credit is limited to one hundred eighty days.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-13-230(A).
Like Â§24-13-210, I would find that Â§ 24-13-230(A) is clear and unambiguous.Â  In my opinion, the legislatureâ€™s use of the word â€œmayâ€ indicates its intention that any reduction in sentence pursuant to Â§ 24-13-230(A) be left to the discretion of DOC.Â Â  See Carolina Power & Light Co. v. Pageland, 321 S.C. 538, 543, 471 S.E.2d 137, 140 (1996) ( holding that when a statuteâ€™s terms are clear and unambiguous on their face, there is no room for statutory construction and a court must apply the statute according to its literal meaning).Â  Stated differently, there is no mandatory requirement that any inmate receive a reduction in sentence under this statute.Â  In fact, despite an inmateâ€™s participation in the programs outlined in the statute, DOC has the discretion to award no sentence reduction at all.Â  Accordingly, I believe that any sentence reduction allowed pursuant to Â§ 24-13-230(A) is not an unfulfilled entitlement, but is completely discretionary.Â  See Skipper v. South Carolina Dept. of Corrections, 370 S.C. 267, 633 S.E.2d 910 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Because an inmate is not entitled to earn credit at a particular level, in my view, an inmate has no protected liberty interest in maintaining a specific work credit level for sentence reduction purposes.Â Â  Cf. Altizer v. Paderick, 569 F.2d 812, 813 (4th Cir. 1978) (finding that classifications and work assignments are discretionary matters for prison administration and â€œto hold that they are â€˜within reach of the procedural protections of the Due Process Clause would place the Clause astride the day-to-day functioning of state prisons and involve the judiciary in issues and discretionary decisions that are not the businessâ€™â€ of the judiciary) (internal citations omitted).Â  
 
Therefore, I would hold that the circuit court did not err in finding no implication of protected liberty interests in the loss of the opportunity to earn sentence-related credits pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 24-13-210 and -230.Â 
 
Finally, while I agree with the majority that the circuit court erred in holding that the ALC lacked subject matter jurisdiction, I would find that no hearing was required under these circumstances.Â  Pursuant to this Courtâ€™s decision in Slezak v. South Carolina Dept. of Corrections, 361 S.C. 327, 331, 605 S.E.2d 506, 508 (2004), the ALC has jurisdiction over all properly perfected inmate appeals.Â  However, the ALC may summarily decide those appeals that do not implicate an inmateâ€™s liberty or property interest and decline to hold a hearing.Â  Id. 
 
DOC does not dispute that Furtick has properly perfected his appeal.Â  Therefore, in my view, the ALC erred in dismissing Furtickâ€™s case on the basis of lack of subject matter jurisdiction.Â  See State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 100, 610 S.E.2d 494, 499 (2005) (noting that subject matter jurisdiction is the power of a court to hear and determine cases of the general class to which the proceedings in question belong).Â  Because I would find that Furtick has no protected liberty interest in unearned sentence-related credits pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 24-13-210(A) and -230(A), I believe the ALC may have summarily decided his appeal without a hearing.Â  Therefore, I would hold that the ALCâ€™s improper dismissal of Furtickâ€™s claim constitutes harmless error.
The federal courts have recognized that, for many prisoners, prolific litigation is a costless pastime.Â  With todayâ€™s decision, this Court unnecessarily throws open the door to judicial review of most any conceivable prison administrative matter virtually assuring this pastime will rapidly become all the more treasured.Â 
 
Thus, with the modification described above, I would affirm the circuit courtâ€™s decision.

[1] According to Furtick, DOC guards entered his cell and seized numerous items of property, including his typewriter, various office supplies, and bleach.Â  It appears the possession of contraband rule infraction was based on the possession of bleach.
[2] As to the facts of the petitionerâ€™s claims in Al-Shabazz, they involved his custody status and the loss of good-time credits incurred as a result of a major disciplinary proceeding.Â  We held that these claims were non-collateral or administrative matters that could not be raised in a PCR application, but could be reviewed under the APA after the DOC reached its final decision.Â  Al-Shabazz,  338 S.C. at 383, 527 S.E.2d at 757.
[3] Regarding Slezakâ€™s grievance which asserted that the prisonâ€™s practice of â€œtriple cellingâ€ constituted a security and health hazard to inmates, the Slezak Court remanded to the ALC for a hearing because it â€œadequately state[d] a violation of appellantâ€™s liberty interest.â€Â  Slezak,Â  361 S.C. at 333, 605 S.E.2d at 508-09.

description: The Court reversed the Court of Appeals. and held that the individual seeking to challenge a DHEC permit had standing to do so.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				James W. Smiley, Petitioner,
				v.
				South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control, Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management, and Wild Dunes Community Association, Respondents.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Charleston County
Â A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26365
Heard April 5, 2007 - Filed July 30, 2007Â  
REVERSED AND REMANDED IN PART; VACATED IN PART


	
		
			
				James S. Chandler, Jr., and Amy E. Armstrong, both of Pawleys Island, for Petitioner.
				CarlisleÂ  Roberts, Jr., of Columbia, and Evander Whitehead, of Charleston, for Respondent SC Department of Health and Environmental Control and Kenneth C. Krawcheck, of Krawcheck & Davidson, of Charleston, for Respondent Wild Dunes Community Association.
			
		
	


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  We granted certiorari to review a Court of Appealsâ€™ decision upholding a finding that petitioner (Smiley) lacked standing to challenge a permit issued by respondent DHECâ€™s Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management (OCRM) to respondent Wild Dunes. [1]Â  Smiley v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health and Envtâ€™l Control, Op. No. 2005-UP-160 (S.C. Ct. App. filed March 7, 2005).Â  We reverse and remand the matter to the Administrative Law Court Division (ALCD).
FACTS
OCRM issued a permit allowing Wild Dunes to periodically excavate sand from the public intertidal beach at the Isle of Palms, if and when erosion occurs, and to transport the sand to Wild Dunesâ€™ private property.Â  This â€œbeach sand scrapingâ€ permit allows Wild Dunes to remove up to 25,000 cubic yards each month from November through April for five years, with the possibility of five-year extensions.Â  The permit limits the depth of scraping to 18 inches: according to calculations in the record, if the maximum amount of sand were extracted, it would affect over ten acres of beach per month.Â  Put another way, if the intertidal beach is assumed to be 300 feet wide, then a â€œfull monthly scrapingâ€ would extend over a space more than 1,400 feet long by 300 feet wide, to a depth of 1 Â½ feet.
 
Following the issuance of the Wild Dunes permit, Smiley requested a contested case hearing before an administrative law judge (ALJ), relying upon S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 48-39-150 and 23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 30-6(A).Â  At that time, Â§ 48-39-150 provided:[2]

	Any person adversely affected by the [OCRMâ€™s] staffâ€™s initial permitting application decision has the right to file a request for a contested case hearing before an administrative law judge.

OCRM filed a motion to dismiss alleging Smiley lacked standing.Â  The ALJ granted the motion, and her ruling was upheld by the Coastal Zone Management Appellate Panel, the circuit court, and the Court of Appeals.
ISSUE

	Whether the Court of Appeals erred in concluding Smiley lacked standing to contest the Wild Dunes permit?

ANALYSIS
The â€œirreducible constitutional minimum of standingâ€ has three components:

	First, the plaintiff must have suffered an â€œinjury in factâ€ - an invasion of a legally protected interest which is (a) concrete and particularized, and (b) â€œactual or imminent, not â€˜conjecturalâ€™ or â€˜hypothetical.â€™â€Â  Second, there must be a causal connection between the injury and the conduct complained of - the injury has to be â€œfairlyâ€¦trace[able] to the challenged action of the defendant, and notâ€¦th[e] result [of] the independent action of some third party not before the court.â€Â  Third, it must be â€œlikely,â€ as opposed to merely â€œspeculative,â€ that the injury will be â€œredressed by a favorable decision.â€
	Lujan v. Defenders of Wildlife, 504 U.S. 555, 560-561 (1992) (internal citations omitted) (Lujan); 
	Sea Pines Assâ€™n for the Protection of Wildlife, Inc. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Natural Resources, 345 S.C. 594, 550 S.E.2d 287 (2001) (Sea Pines).

The ALJâ€™s conclusion, affirmed by the appellate tribunals, that Smiley lacks standing to maintain this action is predicated upon a finding that he cannot meet the first Lujan/Sea Pines element: that he â€œhas suffered an â€˜â€œinjury in factâ€ - an invasion of a legally protected interest which is (a) concrete and particularizedâ€¦and (b) â€œactual or imminent,â€ not â€˜conjecturalâ€™ or â€˜hypothetical.â€™â€Â  Lujan, supra; Sea Pines, supra.Â  In this setting, â€˜particularizedâ€™ means Smiley must be affected in a personal and individualized way by the permitting decision.Â  Id.
Smiley alleged the following facts by affidavit to meet his burden of demonstrating standing:

	I am partially disabled with paralysis of muscles in both legs as a result of a spinal cord injury in 1979.Â  After my release from the hospital in late 1979, I began a course of rehabilitation which continues today and involves jogging on the flat hard public beach on the Isle of Palms.Â  I use the beach in area[s] where sand will be excavated and which is the subject of this proceeding on an almost daily basis.Â  My uses of this beach are for recreation and rehabilitation, including walking, jogging, nature-watching and similar pursuits.Â  Additionally, as an ardent conservationist, responsible citizen and professional biologist, I feel a duty to do my part in preserving and protecting [the] beach/dune system of the Isle of Palms.
	The intrusion of heavy equipment into the public beach and the consequent excavation of sand from the intertidal zone will make it impossible to jog on the beach in the affected area and it will reduce my enjoyment of the beach.Â  FrontEnd [sic] Loaders excavating sand from the beach and bulldozers pushing the sand up onto private property all have a detrimental effect on my aesthetic, conservational and recreational interest and values and will reduce or make impossible my ability to use the beach.

1.Â  â€œActual or imminentâ€
The Court of Appeals held that Smiley failed to meet the requirement that the injury be actual or imminent because while the permit has been issued, no sand has yet been scraped.Â  The court cited its decision in Beaufort Realty Co. v. Beaufort County, 346 S.C. 298, 551 S.E.2d 588 (Ct. App. 2001) (Beaufort Realty) as authority for the holding that until the permit was acted upon, Smiley lacked standing.Â  Smiley contends Beaufort Realty was misapplied.Â  We agree.
In Beaufort Realty, the zoning administrator examined plats filed by Beaufort Realty, and determined that by virtue of the size of the lots and the ingress/egress requirements outlined in the plats, the properties were exempt from a subdivision ordinance.Â  The Court of Appeals held that the conservation group challenging the zoning administratorâ€™s decision to exempt the properties lacked standing as it alleged no injury as a result of the exemption, but instead merely alleged its members would suffer injuries if the properties were someday developed.Â  The conservation group lacked standing as the alleged harm was neither â€œactual nor imminent,â€ it was merely â€œhypothetical or conjectural.â€ In addition to finding the conservation group could not meet the first Lujan/Sea Pines prong, the Beaufort Realty court held the conservation group could not meet the second standing requirement since there was no causal connection between the mere filing of the plats and the alleged potential future harm.Â  Beaufort Realty at 306, 551 S.E.2d at 590.
Smiley argues, and we agree, that to read Beaufort Realty as denying standing to an individual unless and until the â€œinjuryâ€ has been inflicted ignores the â€œactual or imminentâ€ requirement of Lujan/Sea Pines and elevates dicta in Beaufort Realty over its two holdings: that the environmental group was asserting speculative concerns rather than injury, and had failed to demonstrate a causal connection.Â  See e.g. Commander Health Facilities, Inc. v. DHEC, 370 S.C. 296, 634 S.E.2d 664 (Ct. App. 2006) (characterizing Beaufort Realty as requiring either a direct injury or the immediate danger of direct injury).Â  We hold that Smiley has adequately demonstrated that his injury is â€œactual and imminentâ€ for purposes of standing.Â  The Court of Appealsâ€™ holding that his challenge to the Wild Dunes permit is premature is reversed.
B. â€œInjury in factâ€
In a rather confusing paragraph, the Court of Appeals first states that â€œSmiley has failed to demonstrate how the proposed project will prevent his enjoyment of the beach,â€ apparently a finding Smiley has failed to allege â€œa concrete and particularized invasionâ€ of a legally protected interest.Â  The averments in Smileyâ€™s affidavit that he recreates and views nature on the beach on an almost daily basis is a sufficient allegation of a â€œconcrete and particularized invasion.â€Â  As the United States Supreme Court held:

	â€œInjury in factâ€ reflects the statutory requirement that a person be â€œadversely affectedâ€ or â€œaggrieved,â€ and it serves to distinguish a person with a direct stake in the outcome of a litigation - even though small - from a person with a mere interest in the problem.Â  We have allowed important interests to be vindicated by plaintiffs with no more at stake in the outcome of an action than a fraction of a vote,â€¦a $5 fine and costs,â€¦and a $1.50 poll taxâ€¦.Â  [W]e see no reason to adopt a more restrictive interpretation of â€œadversely affectedâ€ or â€œaggrieved.â€Â 
	
	U.S. v. Students Challenging Regulatory Agency Procedures, 412 U.S. 669 (1973) (SCRAP).

Following the statement that Smiley failed to demonstrate how his enjoyment of the beach would be affected, the Court of Appeals went on to say â€œSmileyâ€™s use and enjoyment will be only temporarily alteredâ€ in that â€œhis injury, at best, will be a temporary detour in his jogging route and does not compare to the permanent injury in [citation omitted]â€¦However, even a permanent injury does not assure a plaintiff will have standing [citing Sea Pines][3]â€¦petitionerâ€™s temporary inconvenience does not give rise to standing.â€Â  This is apparently a finding that Smiley failed to allege a sufficient â€œinjury in fact.â€
We are unaware of any legal basis for the Court of Appealsâ€™ distinction of a temporary injury from a permanent injury. Â Moreover, OCRM presented no evidence in opposition to Smileyâ€™s affidavit.Â  There is simply nothing in this record to support the Court of Appealsâ€™ conclusion that any inconvenience will be merely temporary.Â  The court is then critical of Smileyâ€™s averments of injury characterizing them as a temporary detour in his jogging route and ignoring the other â€œuse and enjoymentâ€ claims made in the affidavit.Â  Interference with Smileyâ€™s enjoyment of the beach, and his inability to use it for his rehabilitative jogging for at least six months a year for at least the next five years, are sufficient allegations of a â€œstake in the outcomeâ€ to permit Smiley standing to challenge the permit.Â  SCRAP, supra. 
 
We reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ holding that Smiley merely alleged â€œtemporary inconvenience,â€ and that his allegations are insufficient.Â  Smileyâ€™s affidavit demonstrates that he has a direct stake in the permitting decision, and therefore he sufficiently alleges standing. Â Lujan, supra; Sea Pines, supra.
The Court of Appeals went on to discuss the Public Trust Doctrine and beach renourishment statutes, and conclude that â€œThe excavation of sand does not substantially impair the public interest and is within the Stateâ€™s policy of preserving and restoring its beaches, thus [Smiley] has failed to demonstrate how the permit would violate these protections.â€Â  We vacate, in its entirety, this speculative ruling on the merits of Smileyâ€™s claims, which are not germane to the standing issue.
CONCLUSION
We reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision affirming the rulings that Smiley lacked standing to challenge the Wild Dunes permit, and remand the matter to the ALCD for further proceedings.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.  
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur.

[1] Wild Dunes and OCRM have filed a joint brief in this matter.Â  We will refer to the respondents as OCRM in the opinion.
[2] The statutory scheme was substantially altered in 2006 to conform to the new ALJ/Court of Appeals appellate review scheme.Â  See 2006 Act No. 387.
[3] We note that Sea Pines did not involve a finding of permanent injury with a concomitant denial of standing.Â  Rather, the Court held the plaintiffs presented no evidence that their interest in viewing wildlife would be diminished by the permits, and thus failed to demonstrate â€œany particularized harm.â€Â  Sea Pines, at 606, 550 S.E.2d at 292.Â  Moreover, the Court held that, assuming the Sea Pines plaintiffs had shown an injury, they â€œfailed to present evidence the injury would be redressed by a favorable decisionâ€¦.,â€ Id., that is, they failed to meet the third Lujan standing requirement as well as the first.

title: State v. Weaver
description: This criminal case involves the issue of whether the Court of Appeals erred by upholding the trial court's refusal to suppress evidence found in the vehicle the defendant was driving.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Levell Weaver, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Williamsburg County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26366
Heard February 13, 2007 - Filed July 30, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for petitioner.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Cecil Kelly Jackson, of Sumter, for respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Petitioner was convicted of murder and possession of a weapon during commission of a violent crime.Â  He was sentenced to concurrent imprisonment terms of thirty years for murder and five years for possession of a weapon during a violent crime.Â  His convictions and sentences were upheld on direct appeal by the Court of Appeals.Â  State v. Weaver, 361 S.C. 73, 602 S.E.2d 786 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTS
On June 23, 1999, Marion McKnight was shot thirteen times outside a club and died at the scene.Â  Investigator Sandy Thompson arrived up to an hour after the shooting occurred.Â  Thompson spoke with witnesses still at the club and his investigation led him to search for petitioner.
Thompson received information that petitioner was at the home of his cousin, Arnold Weaver.Â  Thompson and other investigators arrived at Arnoldâ€™s home and found the Jeep, which petitioner was driving earlier that night, in the back yard.Â  Arnold testified petitioner had been at his home, and had asked for a change of clothes, some bleach, and a garbage bag.Â  He left Arnoldâ€™s home less than an hour later.[1]  
Upon finding the Jeep, Thompson and another officer testified Thompson opened the door of the Jeep.Â  After finding the inside of the Jeep was wet and smelled of bleach, Thompson shut the door.Â  The investigators found â€œa bag of washâ€ that smelled like bleach on a pump house near the Jeep.Â  Based on this evidence, the Jeep was impounded and towed to the county jail.
After the Jeep had been impounded, a SLED agent processed the Jeep.Â  The agent testified he found blood in the Jeep in several places, including the interior of the driverâ€™s side door, just below the rear window on the driverâ€™s side, on a chamois cloth found on the back seat of the car, on a keychain found in the ignition, and on the gear shift.Â  The blood matched that of the victim.Â  Further, the rear cargo area was wet and smelled of bleach.Â  This area was positive for blood as well but could not be tested.
Prior to trial, defense counsel moved to suppress the evidence taken from the Jeep.Â  The State noted officers obtained a search warrant before searching the Jeep for blood evidence but after it was impounded in a secure location.Â  However, the return was never made on the warrant as required by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140 (2003).Â  The State indicated they were not relying on the search warrant, but were instead contending it was a valid warrantless search.Â  Therefore, the trial judge analyzed the question of the propriety of the search of the Jeep as if no warrant had been obtained.Â  The trial judge preliminarily ruled the seizure of the Jeep was proper without a warrant, that the search was lawful, and that the evidence was admissible.
Prior to the introduction of Agent Lambertâ€™s testimony regarding the blood evidence, an in camera hearing was held to revisit the admissibility of the testimony.Â  Following the hearing, the judge denied petitionerâ€™s motion to suppress.Â  He stated there was no requirement that a warrantless search occur contemporaneously with the seizure for the automobile exception to the Fourth Amendment to apply.Â  Because he found the warrantless search was proper, the trial judge refused to rule as to whether the officersâ€™ failure to provide a return rendered the search warrant ineffective.Â  The Court of Appeals affirmed.
ISSUE

	Did the Court of Appeals err by upholding the trial courtâ€™s refusal to suppress evidence found in the vehicle petitioner was driving?

DISCUSSION
Petitioner argues the evidence found in the Jeep should have been suppressed.Â  He contends the automobile exception to the Fourth Amendment warrant requirement is inapplicable in this case and, therefore, the State was required to obtain and properly execute a search warrant prior to obtaining evidence from the Jeep.Â  Petitioner states that because the State did not produce a return as required under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140 (2003), the search warrant was invalid and the search of the Jeep was unlawful.Â  In addition, he argues the search violated his rights under Article 1, Â§ 10, of the South Carolina Constitution, because that section provides greater protection than that provided by the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution.
When reviewing a Fourth Amendment search and seizure case, an appellate court must affirm the trial judgeâ€™s ruling if there is any evidence to support the ruling.Â  State v. Missouri, 361 S.C. 107, 603 S.E.2d 594 (2004). Â The appellate court will reverse only when there is clear error. Â Id.

	A.  Was the warrantless search of the Jeep proper pursuant to the automobile exception?

Evidence seized in violation of the Fourth Amendment must be excluded from trial.Â  State v. Freiburger, 366 S.C. 125, 620 S.E.2d 737 (2005), cert. denied, Â Â Â Â Â U.S. Â Â Â Â , 126 S.Ct. 2287 (2006).Â  Generally, a warrantless search is per se unreasonable and violates the Fourth Amendment prohibition against unreasonable searches and seizures. Â Id.Â  However, a warrantless search will withstand constitutional scrutiny where the search falls within one of several well-recognized exceptions to the warrant requirement.Â  Id.Â  One such exception is the automobile exception.Â  State v. Bailey, 276 S.C. 32, 274 S.E.2d 913 (1981).Â  The burden is upon the prosecution to establish probable cause and the existence of circumstances constituting an exception to the general prohibition against warrantless searches.Â  State v. Freiburger, supra.
Pursuant to the automobile exception, if there is probable cause to search a vehicle, a warrant is not necessary so long as the search is based on facts that would justify the issuance of a warrant, even though a warrant has not been actually obtained.Â  Maryland v. Dyson, 527 U.S. 465 (1999).Â  The automobile exception to the search warrant requirement is based on: Â (1) the ready mobility of automobiles and the potential that evidence may be lost or destroyed before a warrant is obtained and (2) the lessened expectation of privacy in motor vehicles which are subject to government regulation.Â  State v. Cox, 290 S.C. 489, 351 S.E.2d 570 (1986).Â  The automobile exception does not contain a separate exigency requirement.Â  Maryland v. Dyson, supra.Â  If a vehicle is readily mobile and probable cause exists to believe it contains contraband, the Fourth Amendment permits police to search the vehicle without more.Â  Pennsylvania v. Labron, 518 U.S. 938 (1996).
In the instant case, there was probable cause to conduct a warrantless search of the Jeep.Â  Investigators knew that petitioner, a suspect in McKnightâ€™s murder, had been seen driving the Jeep around the time of the murder.Â Â  Upon finding the Jeep, it seemed apparent there had been an attempt to destroy evidence given the Jeepâ€™s interior was wet and smelled of bleach.Â  Therefore, upon finding the Jeep, the investigators could have conducted the search at that time; however, they chose to impound the vehicle.
The fact investigators chose to wait to search the Jeep after it had already been impounded does not affect the propriety of the warrantless search because there is no requirement that the warrantless search of a vehicle occur contemporaneously with its lawful seizure.Â  United States v. Johns, 469 U.S. 478 (1985) (upholding warrantless search that occurred three days after seizure).Â  See also Florida v. Myers, 466 U.S. 380 (1984) (warrantless search of vehicle, which was impounded and in police custody, conducted several hours after valid initial search conducted at time of defendantâ€™s arrest, was proper); Cooper v. State of California, 386 U.S. 58 (1967) (it is no answer to say the police could have obtained a search warrant, for the relevant test is not whether it is reasonable to procure a search warrant, but whether the search was reasonable).Â  The justification to conduct such a warrantless search does not vanish once the car has been immobilized. Â United State v. Johns, supra.
Accordingly, the warrantless search meets the automobile exception to the Fourth Amendment.Â  However, before concluding the evidence recovered from the Jeep is admissible, we must examine petitionerâ€™s argument that our state constitution provides him with greater protection.

	B. Does the State constitution provide greater protection than the United States Constitution?

Petitioner argues that the search and seizure of the Jeep violates the state constitution because of the location of the Jeep when it was seized, i.e. in the back yard of a private residence.Â  He argues the invasion of his privacy was not reasonable based on that fact.
The Fourth Amendment to the United States Constitution prohibits unreasonable searches and seizures:Â  â€œThe right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects, against unreasonable searches and seizures, shall not be violated . . . .â€Â  U.S. Const. amend. IV.Â  The South Carolina Constitution also provides a safeguard against unlawful searches and seizures.Â  State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 541 S.E.2d 837 (2001) (citing S.C. Const. art. I. Â§ 10).Â  The relationship between the two constitutions is significant because â€œ[s]tate courts may afford more expansive rights under state constitutional provisions than the rights which are conferred by the Federal Constitution.â€Â  Id. (quoting State v. Easler, 327 S.C. 121, 131, n. 13, 489 S.E.2d 617, 625, n. 13 (1997)).Â  Therefore, this Court may interpret the state protection against unreasonable searches and seizures in such a way as to provide greater protection than the federal Constitution.Â  Id.
In addition to language that mirrors the Fourth Amendment, S.C. Const. art. 1 Â§ 10 contains an express protection of the right to privacy: â€œThe right of the people to be secure in their persons, houses, papers, and effects against unreasonable searches and seizures and unreasonable invasions of privacy shall not be violated . . . .â€Â  State v. Forrester, supra (emphasis added).Â  By articulating a specific prohibition against â€œunreasonable invasions of privacy,â€ the people of South Carolina have indicated that searches and seizures that do not offend the federal Constitution may still offend the South Carolina Constitution.Â  Id.Â  Accordingly, the South Carolina Constitution favors an interpretation offering a higher level of privacy protection than the Fourth Amendment.Â  Id.
The question is whether this privacy provision goes so far as to require a warrant before the search and seizure of a vehicle located in the back yard of a private residence. Â We find there is no meaningful distinction to be made between vehicles parked in public and private places.[2]Â  See State v. Cox, 290 S.C. 489, 351 S.E.2d 570 (1986) (finding seizure of shotgun from trunk of murder defendantâ€™s vehicle, which was parked in yard of his house at time of search, was valid under automobile exception to warrant requirement).Â  The focus in the state constitution is on whether the invasion of privacy is reasonable, regardless of the personâ€™s expectation of privacy in the vehicle to be searched.Â  Once the officers have probable cause to search a vehicle, the state constitutionâ€™s requirement that the invasion of oneâ€™s privacy be reasonable will be met.Â  We find the invasion of petitionerâ€™s privacy was reasonable because the officers had probable cause to search where petitioner had apparently used the Jeep to leave the scene of a murder and attempted to destroy evidence of the crime that was located inside the Jeep.Â  Accordingly, the search of the Jeep satisfied the requirements of the South Carolina Constitution.

	C.  Was the Search Warrant Valid?

Because the automobile exception applies in this case and the warrantless search of the vehicle was proper, it is unnecessary to address whether the warrant was invalid because a return was not made.Â  However, we address this issue to correct the Court of Appealsâ€™ ruling on this issue.
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140 (2003) requires search warrants to be executed and return made within ten days after the date of the warrant.[3]Â  The failure to observe the ten-day requirement for the execution and return of a warrant, a ministerial requirement, does not necessarily void the warrant.Â  State v. Wise, 272 S.C. 384, 252 S.E.2d 294 (1979).Â  The warrant will be invalidated only if the defendant can show he was prejudiced by the failure.Â  Id.Â  See also State v. Mollison, 319 S.C. 41, 459 S.E.2d 88 (Ct. App. 1995) (failure to comply with inconsequential ministerial requirements of the statute does not require suppression in the absence of prejudice to the defendant).
The Court of Appeals held the Stateâ€™s failure to produce a return constituted more than a ministerial error.Â  We find the Court of Appeals erred because petitioner did not show he was prejudiced by the Stateâ€™s failure to comply with the return requirement.Â  See State v. Wise, supra (warrant not voided where appellant failed to show he was prejudiced by Stateâ€™s failure to return warrant to issuing magistrate within ten-day period); State v. Mollison, supra (evidence not suppressed where appellants did not argue they were prejudiced in any way by the failure to return the warrant within ten days).Â  Accordingly, the Stateâ€™s failure to comply with the statutory ministerial requirement does not void the warrant and the evidence can not be excluded on this ground.
CONCLUSION
We find that if the requirements of probable cause and ready mobility are met, then the search is permissible pursuant to the State constitution and the United States Constitution.Â  Because we find the search was a proper warrantless search, it is unnecessary to determine whether the Stateâ€™s failure to make a return rendered the warrant ineffective.Â  However, we note that where the defendant fails to argue he was prejudiced by the Stateâ€™s failure to comply with the return requirement, the warrant will not be voided and evidence cannot be excluded on that ground.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the Court of Appeals is
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
WALLER and BURNETT, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., concurring in a separate opinion in which TOAL, C.J., concurs.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â Â Â Â Â Â  I concur in the majorityâ€™s conclusion that the warrantless search and seizure in this case did not violate the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution or Article I, section 10 of the South Carolina Constitution which prohibits unreasonable invasions of privacy.Â  I also agree that the Stateâ€™s failure to produce a return to the search warrant did not invalidate the warrant in this case.Â  I write separately, however, because I disagree with the majorityâ€™s analysis of the vehicle seizure under the South Carolina Constitution.
The automobile exception to the search warrant requirement of the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution is based on: (1) the ready mobility of automobiles and (2) the lessened expectation of privacy in motor vehicles which are subject to government regulation.Â  California v. Carney, 471 U.S. 386 (1985).Â  The South Carolina Constitution specifically prohibits â€œunreasonable invasions of privacy,â€ and this Court has stated, as the majority recognizes, that our constitution â€œfavors an interpretation offering a higher level of privacy protection than the Fourth Amendment.â€Â  State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 541 S.E.2d 837 (2001).
In determining whether South Carolinaâ€™s privacy provision requires a warrant before the search and seizure of a vehicle located in the backyard of a private residence, the majority focuses on one justification for the automobile exception: the inherent mobility of the vehicle.Â  This analysis is incomplete.Â  We must further analyze the impact of this provision on the second prong of a Fourth Amendment automobile analysis, that is, the expectation of privacy in a private automobile.Â  A holding that â€œthe inherent mobility of the vehicle is all that is required to satisfy the state constitutionâ€ implies a lower degree of protection than that provided by the Fourth Amendment when addressing warrantless searches and seizures.Â  This conflicts with our prior cases.Â  See Forrester, supra.
Furthermore, the majorityâ€™s reliance on State v. Cox, 290 S.C. 489, 351 S.E.2d 570 (1986), is, in my opinion, misplaced.Â  The search and seizure issue in Cox was analyzed solely under the Fourth Amendment and did not discuss Article I, section 10 of the South Carolina Constitution.Â  Moreover, search and seizure cases analyzed under the Fourth Amendment have made distinctions between vehicles parked in public and private places.Â  See G.M. Leasing Corp. v. U.S., 429 U.S. 338, 351-52 (1977) (holding the warrantless seizure of vehicles did not violate the Fourth Amendment because â€œ[t]he seizures of the automobiles in this case took place on public streets, parking lots, or other open places, and did not involve any invasion of privacy.â€); Florida v. White, 526 U.S. 559 (1999) (noting the distinction between a warrantless seizure in an open area and a seizure made on private premises and concluding that because the police seized respondentâ€™s vehicle from a public area, the warrantless seizure did not involve any invasion of respondentâ€™s privacy); and Binder v. Redford Tp. Police Dept., 93 Fed.Appx. 701 (6th Cir. 2004) (â€œAlthough probable cause suffices for the search or seizure of vehicles parked on public property [or even private property that is accessible to the public], no Supreme Court decision allows warrantless entry into areas of a home or business where the owner has a reasonable expectation of privacy simply because the police are in search of an automobile.â€) (citing G.M. Leasing Corp., supra).
Analysis of the facts of this case with our privacy provision in mind reveals no state constitutional violation.Â  Although oneâ€™s expectation of privacy in his automobile increases when that automobile is parked in the backyard of his private residence, the petitioner in this case was not the owner of the Jeep that was seized.[4]Â  More importantly, the vehicle was not parked at petitionerâ€™s residence.Â  
 
Our state constitutionâ€™s provision protecting unreasonable invasions of privacy necessarily requires some analysis of the privacy interests involved when a warrantless seizure is made on private property.Â  However, petitioner cannot show he had a reasonable expectation of privacy in the seized Jeep.Â  Accordingly, I concur in the result reached by the majority.
TOAL, C.J., concurs.

[1] Petitioner turned himself in during the early morning hours of June 24. 
 
[2] The concurrence asserts that search and seizure cases analyzed under the Fourth Amendment have made distinctions between vehicles parked in public and private places.Â  However, there has never been a clear statement by the United States Supreme Court that a warrant is required before a vehicle is searched in a private place.Â  In fact, the Fourth Circuit has stated there should not be a bright-line rule that the automobile exception may never apply when a vehicle is stationed on private, residential property.Â  United States v. Brookins, 345 F.3d 231, 237 (4th Cir. 2003).
[3] â€œ. . . Any warrant issued hereunder shall be executed and return made only within ten days after it is dated. The officer executing the warrant shall make and deliver a signed inventory of any articles seized by virtue of the warrant, which shall be delivered to the judicial officer to whom the return is to be made, and if a copy of the inventory is demanded by the person from whose person or premises the property is taken, a copy of the inventory shall be delivered to him. . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 17-13-140 (2003).
[4] The record reveals that petitioner was one of several family members who had permission to use the Jeep.
